headline: Fluor Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good afternoon, and welcome to Fluor Corporation's Fourth Quarter and Year-end 2015 Conference Call. Today's call is being recorded. [Operator Instructions] A replay of today's conference call will be available at approximately 8:30 p.m. Eastern Time toda
componenttext:
Good afternoon, and welcome to Fluor Corporation's Fourth Quarter and Year-end 2015 Conference Call. Today's call is being recorded. [Operator Instructions] A replay of today's conference call will be available at approximately 8:30 p.m. Eastern Time today, accessible on Fluor's website at www.fluor.com. The web replay will be available for 30 days. A telephone replay will also be available through 7:30 p.m. Eastern Time on  February 24, at the following telephone number, (888) 203-1112. The passcode of 590-4252 will be required. 
At this time, for opening remarks, I would like to turn the call over to Geoff Telfer, Senior Vice President of Investor Relations. Please go ahead, Mr. Telfer.

headline: Fluor Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Justin, and welcome to Fluor's Fourth Quarter 2015 Conference Call. With us today are David Seaton, Fluor's Chairman and Chief Executive Officer; and Biggs Porter, Fluor's Chief Financial Officer. Our earnings announcement was released this a
componenttext:
Thank you, Justin, and welcome to Fluor's Fourth Quarter 2015 Conference Call. With us today are David Seaton, Fluor's Chairman and Chief Executive Officer; and Biggs Porter, Fluor's Chief Financial Officer. 
Our earnings announcement was released this afternoon after market close, and we have posted a slide presentation on our website, which we'll reference while making prepared remarks. But before getting started, I'd like to refer you to our Safe Harbor note regarding forward-looking statements, which is summarized on Slide 2. 
During today's call and slide presentation, we'll be making forward-looking statements, which reflect our current analysis of existing trends and information. However, there is an inherent risk that actual results could differ materially. You can find a discussion of our risk factors, which could potentially contribute to such differences in the company's Form 10-K, which was filed earlier today. 
During today's call, we may also discuss certain non-GAAP financial measures. Reconciliations of these amounts with the comparable GAAP measures are reflected in our earnings release and posted in the Investor Relations section of our website at investors.fluor.com. 
Now I'll turn the call over to David Seaton, Fluor's Chairman and CEO. David?

headline: Fluor Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Jeff. Good afternoon, everyone, and thank you for joining us. On today's call, we'll review our fourth quarter and full year of 2015 as well as discuss our outlook for 2016. Before we talk about our fourth quarter and full-year results, I do want
componenttext:
Thanks, Jeff. Good afternoon, everyone, and thank you for joining us. On today's call, we'll review our fourth quarter and full year of 2015 as well as discuss our outlook for 2016. Before we talk about our fourth quarter and full-year results, I do want to spend a few minutes to share my perspective on the markets we serve. 
Global economic growth continues to be weak and commodity prices remain low. We expect economic growth for the year to be similar of the past few years, yet we also expect commodity prices to stabilize during this year and perhaps even begin to improve in the last part of the year. The lower commodity prices obviously, continue to impact our customers cash flows and therefore, their ability to fund certain projects at the same pace that they've done previously. 
Many of our customers have already announced significant reductions in their capital expenditure budgets for 2016. However, Fluor serves a diverse portfolio of industries and regions. This provides the company opportunities even in difficult market environments. While low oil prices may delay some oil and gas projects, Fluor is focused on our clients and their spending priorities. 
As I've mentioned in the past, we continue to see the FID on large greenfield LNG facilities to move to the right as clients focus on opportunities to improve capital efficiency. By that extension, it's important to note that we do not anticipate any material contributions from LNG projects during 2016. Our Power business should experience strong growth this year with the Westinghouse projects now fully transitioned plus the business is experiencing an uptick in gas-related projects. 
Our government and infrastructure markets are also experiencing growth with key recent wins, including the $1.4 billion nuclear cleanup project in Idaho and the Arizona Loop 202 [ph] project. We also expect to hear shortly the outcome of our bid to build the 16-mile purple line light rail project in Maryland. We continue to implement our integrated solution strategy. Our strategy focuses on delivering the full spectrum of capital efficient solutions for our customers. 
We've taken significant steps in 2015 to broaden our offering, including expanding our global fabrication footprint with the announcement of the joint venture in China and extending our position in the construction and maintenance markets through the Westinghouse Nuclear Awards and our upcoming acquisition store. While we're talking about fabrication investments and historic acquisition, let me give you an update on the closings status. Our JV with and the Zhuhai fabrication continues to progress. We're receiving final approvals now and expect to make our first payment in the next few months. 
Back in December, we announced the intent to acquire a new store, a maintenance and modification and asset integrity company based in The Netherlands. Stork enhances not only our current offering, but creates tremendous opportunity to leverage our combined capabilities and brands across a broad spectrum of opportunities. We anticipate this transactions to also close in the next few months. 
While we expect 2016 to be another challenging year, our focus will be on the things that we can control. Now let's look at our 2015 full year results beginning with Slide 5 -- Slide 3. Excluding a pretax nonoperating pension settlement expense of $240 million, net earnings attributable to Fluor from continuing operations were $571 million or $3.89 per diluted share compared with $715 million or $4.48 per diluted share a year ago. 
Consolidated segment profit for 2015 was $1 billion, which compares to $1.3 billion a year ago. Despite volatile oil prices, our Oil & Gas segment performed very well during the year contributing $764 million in segment profit, a 14% increase over 2014. However, this increase was offset by the decline in other segments. Segment profits -- profit margins were 5.7%, which compares with 5.9% a year ago. 
Consolidated 2015 revenue was $18.1 billion, down from $21.5 billion a year ago. Full-year new awards were $21.8 billion [ph], including $11 billion in Oil & Gas, $6 billion in Power, $3.2 billion in Industrial Infrastructure and $1.4 billion in Government. Consolidated backlog for the year ended -- ending was $44.7 billion, up 5% from $42.5 billion a year ago. Our clients have not given any indication that they intend to cancel any ongoing projects with us. 
Turning to Slide 4. The Oil & Gas segment with $2.1 billion in new awards, including 2 Pemex refining projects in Mexico. Ending backlog for that segment was $28.8 billion, which compares to $28.5 billion in 2014. Fourth quarter new awards in industrial infrastructure were $302 million. We closed the year with a backlog of $5.6 billion compared to $7.2 billion at the end of 2014, which reflects the reduced Mining & Metals new award activity. 
The Government group posted fourth quarter new awards of $352 million and they're ending backlog in 2015 was $3.6 billion. Turning to Slide 5 in the Power segment. Fourth quarter new awards were $5.1 billion, including award for 2 reimbursable contracts with Westinghouse Electric Co. to manage the construction workforce at 2 nuclear power plants in Georgia and South Carolina. Ending backlog for 2015 was $6.8 billion, which compares to $2.1 billion a year ago. 
Segment profit for the fourth quarter was impacted by a $31 million charge related to a gas Fluor power facility in Brunswick County Virginia. This is primarily related to commissioning, taking longer than expected due to changes and challenges associated with the installation of the gas turbines, which extended past the third quarter. This project has reached mechanical completion and we anticipate turning this project over to the customer in spring. 
With that, now I'll turn the call over to Biggs to review some of the details of our operating performance and the core financial metrics for the quarter. Biggs?

headline: Fluor Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, David, and good afternoon, everyone. Please turn to Slide 6 of the presentation. I'll start by providing some additional comments on our fourth quarter performance then move to the balance sheet. Revenue for the quarter was $4.4 billion, which c
componenttext:
Thanks, David, and good afternoon, everyone. Please turn to Slide 6 of the presentation. I'll start by providing some additional comments on our fourth quarter performance then move to the balance sheet. 
Revenue for the quarter was $4.4 billion, which compares to $5.5 billion a year ago. All segments reported slight year-over-year reductions with the exception of industrial infrastructure, which experienced a 41% decline mainly due to the continued reduction in mining activity. Excluding the pension settlement expense of $231 million, or $1.04 per diluted share in the quarter, EPS from continuing operations for the fourth quarter was $0.68 compared to $1.41 a year ago. 
Including pension settlement expenses, the company reported a loss of $51 million or $0.36 per diluted share. This quarter's EPS was negatively impacted by approximately $0.21 per share due to the combined effect of the $31 million charge on the Brunswick Power project and the higher-than-expected tax rate due to losses in 2 foreign subsidiaries that we weren't able to benefit for U.S. tax purposes. These tax effects converse in the future. 
Over the course of the year, we received a few questions about the impact of foreign exchange rates on the P&L. Looking at the impact of FX on a quarterly basis, there is very little variation. However, when you look at FX from a yearly impact, 2015 versus 2014, using average rates of both periods, there is a negative impact to EPS of approximately $0.20. Corporate G&A expenses in the fourth quarter was $54 million compared to $53 million a year ago. 
Shifting to the balance sheet. Fluor's financial position remains very strong with cash plus current and noncurrent marketable securities totaling $2.4 billion, flat with a year ago. In 2015, the company generated $849 million in cash flow from operating activities compared to $643 million in 2014. The company also returned $635 million in cash to shareholders through share repurchases and dividends. 
In the first quarter 2015 as you recall, we also settled a claim for dispute operations of $306 million. Absent that, cash flow from operations would be even stronger. The previously announced $1 billion share repurchase program was completed in the fourth quarter of 2014 till the end of 2015. For the year, we repurchased 10,105,000 shares. On February 4, 2016, the Board of Directors increased our outstanding share repurchase reauthorization by 10 million shares. However, although our cash position is strong at year-end, everyone should keep in mind that we have existing near-term commitments for our cash. 
Moving to Slide 7. Fluor's consolidated backlog at year-end was $44.7 billion. The percentage of fixed price contracts in our overall backlog was 22% at quarter end, and the mix by geography was 41% U.S. and 59% non-U.S. For the year, backlog was negatively impacted by about $3 billion as a result of the strong dollar. 
I will conclude my remarks by commenting on our guidance for 2016, which is on Slide 8. We are maintaining our guidance for 2016 at $3.50 to $4 per share. Our guidance for 2016 also assumed G&A expense in the range of $190 million to $200 million and a tax rate of 33% to 35%. Other expectations for 2016 include NuScale expenses of approximately $90 million as we get to DC Apus submittal ledger this year, capital expenditures of approximately $300 million and our payments to fund our joint venture with COOEC of $350 million in the first half and $140 million in the third quarter of this year. Our guidance does not include any benefit related to our acquisition of Stork nor any transaction and integration-related costs. This transaction is expected to close as early as March. Our guidance reflects that expectation of gradual quarterly improvement in 2016. 
With that operator, we're ready to take questions.

headline: Fluor Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016

componenttextpreview: David, so look, we know new awards are lumpy. But just trying to think about how to think about them going forward. So x the nuclear projects, you booked close to 3 billion of work, and most of that oil and gas. Maybe you can talk about what you think rig
componenttext: David, so look, we know new awards are lumpy. But just trying to think about how to think about them going forward. So x the nuclear projects, you booked close to 3 billion of work, and most of that oil and gas. Maybe you can talk about what you think right now is sort of the underpinnings of work in a more difficult environment. Should this be the minimum that you generally have in any quarter, like a 3 billion number, again x nuclear? Or was 4Q phenomenally low? And could you average higher in '16? Just how do we think about it going forward?

headline: Fluor Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I mean, that's a great question. I think it's going to be even more lumpy in '16 than we've seen in the past. The -- what we're going to see is that many of the customers are still taking an extra quarter or so to make their decision. So we run the r
componenttext: Yes, I mean, that's a great question. I think it's going to be even more lumpy in '16 than we've seen in the past. The -- what we're going to see is that many of the customers are still taking an extra quarter or so to make their decision. So we run the risk of having a project go from first quarter to second quarter, second quarter to third quarter. So I think it's going to be somewhat more lumpy and I believe back-end loaded more so this year than in previous years. We still have a -- I mean, it is a robust plan that's synonymous with the former year in terms of things we're looking at. So I feel good about the total number. But it's just going to be a little bit of a dance here at the end of the quarter based on what decisions our customers make. We are getting indications that many of these customers are moving forward to FID on some of these programs and projects. So it gives us confidence that we'll be able to book these things. But given a lot of clarity right now in terms of what quarter they'll come in, I really can't provide that right now.

headline: Fluor Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. That's helpful, David. So okay, you ended up recording 7.6% margin in Oil & Gas that's obviously, an impressive result. You talked about '16 a little before, I think you guys have talked about low 6% Oil & Gas margins where you can end up in '16. No
componenttext: Okay. That's helpful, David. So okay, you ended up recording 7.6% margin in Oil & Gas that's obviously, an impressive result. You talked about '16 a little before, I think you guys have talked about low 6% Oil & Gas margins where you can end up in '16. Now if Oil & Gas stays weaker for longer, can you sustain that kind of margin? How much more cost out opportunity do you have in Oil & Gas? How do we get a read on these very high margins in a modestly weaker environment for you guys.

headline: Fluor Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I'll answer it this way. I think our teams have done an outstanding job in terms of what they brought in the backlog. And the quality of earnings in backlog has not taken a hit, a significant hit. We've really -- I'm really pleased with the way the
componenttext: Well, I'll answer it this way. I think our teams have done an outstanding job in terms of what they brought in the backlog. And the quality of earnings in backlog has not taken a hit, a significant hit. We've really -- I'm really pleased with the way the organization has responded. I'm really pleased with the way the market in particular, our customers respond to this integrated solutions model, which gives us confidence that number one, that strategy is working and is welcomed by our customers. And two, is producing the kind of margins that we expect to get. So I feel pretty good about the quality of earnings that are in our backlog. Now that does not mean there hasn't been pricing pressures in certain markets. It doesn't mean there won't be pricing pressures going forward. But I think maintaining that kind of a level during '16 is quite doable.

headline: Fluor Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'm not even going to go -- I'm not even going to start on Power, I'll let someone else do that. But anyway, I guess, my first question relates to the guidance for 2016. I guess I was bit surprised that you maintained your guide given that you don't assum
componenttext: I'm not even going to go -- I'm not even going to start on Power, I'll let someone else do that. But anyway, I guess, my first question relates to the guidance for 2016. I guess I was bit surprised that you maintained your guide given that you don't assume any contribution from Stork, which I get because it haven't closed yet. But just based on your commentary that customers are slowing spend over a longer period of time. You knew that you had Westinghouse when you initially gave your guide in the third quarter doesn't seem like tax rate has changed. I'm just trying to get a sense of -- have the puts and takes of the guidance changed relative to -- and even though we're still at the same place relative to where we were last quarter? And then David, I guess my other question to you is, Andy is trying to ask about oil and gas revenue and operating profit for 2016 our margins. But I guess my concern is or what I'm trying to understand is, how do I think about the run rate of oil and gas profits as we exit the year? Because my concern I guess, is more as we think about '17, if awards don't materialize this year in oil and gas, which I don't think they do, how do we think about how materially down earnings can be in 2017 because I can't think of a good reason why, outside of what we know about Westinghouse and Stork, why the other businesses could actually sort of make up for the decline that we're going to see in oil and gas?

headline: Fluor Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Jamie, it's kind of interesting -- I don't really want to talk about '17 yet. I want to make sure we deliver in '16. But our diversity does provide -- those puts and takes you mentioned. Yes, there have been puts and takes that keeps us at guidance where
componenttext: Jamie, it's kind of interesting -- I don't really want to talk about '17 yet. I want to make sure we deliver in '16. But our diversity does provide -- those puts and takes you mentioned. Yes, there have been puts and takes that keeps us at guidance where we are, which is a value of the diversity that we enjoy. If we were just an oil and gas company, you'd probably have seen us reduce things like a lot of other folks have over the last few quarters. But that diversity pays off. The ability to take on big projects in Power helps our earnings stream. Our ability to do operations and some maintenance work. Our ability to work in the pharmaceutical business and the infrastructure sector, all helps us from a diversity standpoint maintain our earnings power. So I think that we got the opportunity to perform as we suggested at the end of the third quarter. Relative to oil and gas, right now as we see it, the year will be reasonably strong. And as we enter '17, assuming that a couple of things happen that we anticipate, '17 should be equally as strong in terms of oil and gas. So I guess, there's a bit of a bearish tone in terms of the overall and most of that bearish tone is coming from the press. I'm fairly bullish about our ability to deliver on '16. I'm pretty bullish about our position in the marketplace and backlog as at least stay flat with backlog as we enter '17. The glass is half full and I don't see the doom and gloom that a lot of people or I guess, your question kind of leads us towards.

headline: Fluor Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I guess, just to be clear, you said operating profit in oil and gas should still be relatively strong or comparable to what we're going to see in '16?
componenttext: Well, I guess, just to be clear, you said operating profit in oil and gas should still be relatively strong or comparable to what we're going to see in '16?

headline: Fluor Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016

componenttext: Probably down some from -- if you had a whole dollar basis from '16 -- or from '15 excuse me, Jamie, going on into '16. But as David says, its still strong. It's not our steepest decline, but to some degree, a decline there. So it's reflected somewhat by the lower margin rate that we've already led you to.

headline: Fluor Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: But, no. I was more interested I guess in his '17 commentary that it could still be pretty strong. I guess, my question would be if there's no big LNG project sitting, it doesn't sound like TCO is going to go anytime soon. So I'm just trying to figure out
componenttext: But, no. I was more interested I guess in his '17 commentary that it could still be pretty strong. I guess, my question would be if there's no big LNG project sitting, it doesn't sound like TCO is going to go anytime soon. So I'm just trying to figure out what I'm missing on what you could broke in terms of saying backlog can be flat with where we ended this year as we exit the year.

headline: Fluor Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Jamie, there's a lot of things out there and people are still spending money. I mean everybody wants to talk about LNG and TCO. But we were 3 -- we went 4 packages on refineries in Kuwait. We've won 2 projects in refining in Mexico. We've won refining pro
componenttext: Jamie, there's a lot of things out there and people are still spending money. I mean everybody wants to talk about LNG and TCO. But we were 3 -- we went 4 packages on refineries in Kuwait. We've won 2 projects in refining in Mexico. We've won refining projects in the United States with Sorrow and some others. So there's a lot of spending going on and we're not hanging our hat on 1 or 2 projects. We, as a company, have over 2,500 active project at any given time and that's what gives us the strength and the confidence to be able to say we've got a good solid hope. Obviously, this guy could fall. But assuming that it doesn't, we should be in a good position as we end '16.

headline: Fluor Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: And sorry, I promise I won't ask another question, just a clarification. The backlog comment, was that related to oil and gas or the total company, when you said it could be flat by the end of '16?
componenttext: And sorry, I promise I won't ask another question, just a clarification. The backlog comment, was that related to oil and gas or the total company, when you said it could be flat by the end of '16?

headline: Fluor Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016

headline: Fluor Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: David, how would you describe the flow of FEED work at the moment? Because obviously, that tends to be more steady. I guess, I'm just kind of wondering what you experienced in terms of the change in pace and fees in the last few months. And maybe as you'r
componenttext: David, how would you describe the flow of FEED work at the moment? Because obviously, that tends to be more steady. I guess, I'm just kind of wondering what you experienced in terms of the change in pace and fees in the last few months. And maybe as you're thinking about the whole company, which end markets are you seeing the most new FEED work come in and which is the least, and that kind of trends transitions into a question of about service? Is there a base level of oil and gas bookings that you  think you can see over the next year as a result of kind of FEED and kind of flow kind of work?

headline: Fluor Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I think you've got to peel the onion on oil and gas back a little bit. But let me talk about the other group spurs. We're seeing an uptick in opportunity in the infrastructure group. They kind of hit a low as you ended '14 and early '15. And we're s
componenttext: Well, I think you've got to peel the onion on oil and gas back a little bit. But let me talk about the other group spurs. We're seeing an uptick in opportunity in the infrastructure group. They kind of hit a low as you ended '14 and early '15. And we're seeing a significant slate of opportunities a bit are there. And part of that is I think the U.S. government focus on infrastructure and the things that are necessary to keep the U.S. economy going. So that's a bright spot. We're seeing an uptick in terms of pharmaceutical biotech opportunities with the FDA, approving drugs. Some of those projects are getting off of a -- off to mark. We're seeing a significant amount of front end work, steady work on gas-fired power plants and we see a pretty robust opportunities slate there. When you look at oil and gas though, you got to peel the onion and peel it this way: Number one, there is no drilling going on. The rig -- you can read the rig counts just like anybody else. We don't have any exposure to that. You can look at the big deepwater drilling, the horizontal drilling and some difficult places obviously, lesson learned. We don't do that either. We are seeing however, a fair amount of work in traditional offshore and traditional onshore upstream oil and gas and significant FEED work in those areas because they're -- the oil companies are kind of taking their deep breath and they're looking at, okay, what are the priorities? And I know those priorities are coming out as studies and FEEDs in those markets. And those are slow, but they're calming. I think the FEED activity that's picked up as I said earlier has been in refining and it continues to be in petrochemicals and fine chemicals. So you got to kind of peel the onion and the things that we have exposure to, we're seeing a pretty robust slate of front end work that again, gives us kind of flexibility going back to Jamie's question about '17. We've got good visibility into the priority of the projects that our customers are taking, the economic viability of those projects based on current economic factors and that's what leads us to say that we'll have a pretty robust reward slate that -- and robust to me means equal to this year and certainly, provides some visibility into the opportunities for '17. So again, I go back to what I said during Jamie's question, the glass is half-full and it's half-full for us because of the fact that we've really stepped to our customers and we've answered their call for integrated solutions and capital efficiencies.

headline: Fluor Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016

headline: Fluor Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. That's helpful. I guess you just sort of just answered this question, but it's sort of a bigger picture thing, about to what extent that this commodity price backdrop and macro really causing you to rethink the way you do business versus just kind o
componenttext: Okay. That's helpful. I guess you just sort of just answered this question, but it's sort of a bigger picture thing, about to what extent that this commodity price backdrop and macro really causing you to rethink the way you do business versus just kind of the cost restructuring you did, and some of these strategic moves you might've done anyway. Really just trying to gauge your perspective on how much hunkering down and really rethinking your overall business model there needs to be here? I mean it sounds like, like you said, the kind of glass is half-full and there's a lot out there. But I mean, do you feel the need to really think the way things are going or are they that sort of dire? It sounds like not.

headline: Fluor Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: That's a great question. I was in an event this morning at the Dallas bid, and the same kind of discussion was taking place. It's interesting. I remember it and I've said it on these calls before and in private meetings with you guys, I was sent to Saudi
componenttext: That's a great question. I was in an event this morning at the Dallas bid, and the same kind of discussion was taking place. It's interesting. I remember it and I've said it on these calls before and in private meetings with you guys, I was sent to Saudi Arabia in 1997 and oil was $17 a barrel, up from $11. This isn't the first time me or people within our industry or our company, have seen this kind of swings and volatility in markets. And they will fix themselves. I mean, when you think right now, there's an oversupply of oil products. There's an oversupply of gas. There's an oversupply of LNG. It's going to take a while for that to clear, but it will clear. And when you think about particularly oil and gas customers, they haven't said they're going to stop spending. They said they're going to cut their capital spending. And that just means that they're going to prioritize and look at those high valued projects, which is one of the litmus tests or selectivity says that we use in terms of what projects we actually pursue. So again, I think our strategy is sound in terms of how we want to face the market and how we want to deal with the customers and which projects do we want to prioritize on. But that does not mean that we're not going to continue to look at our strategy, focus on cash management, focus on lower -- continuing to find areas of how we do our projects to lower cost to meet that demand that the customers asking for in terms of capital efficiency. So we're going to continue to work. And as I said in the prepared remarks, focus on the things that we can control. And right now, that's how we focus on the customers and how we sell a different way of doing projects that delivers what they're asking for.

headline: Fluor Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: And next, we'll come Andrew Whitman with Baird.
componenttext: And next, we'll come Andrew Whitman with Baird.

headline: Fluor Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: There was a comment in the 10-K that you expect 38% of the backlog to burn this year. That implies about $17 billion of revenue. So I guess, 2 parts from here. How much book and burn do you think is available to you with your current outlook here? And the
componenttext: There was a comment in the 10-K that you expect 38% of the backlog to burn this year. That implies about $17 billion of revenue. So I guess, 2 parts from here. How much book and burn do you think is available to you with your current outlook here? And then when we kind of marry that $17 billion number, so I mean there is any burning book in there, we know there is. But it does imply that margins are probably in the high 4% range. Can you just kind of give your thoughts on the implicit margins from that and the book and burn more, if it's available to you this year.

headline: Fluor Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, that sort of a back end way to kind of give us real revenue guidance and there's a fair amount of variability in terms of mix as we know, how we experience over the last couple of years on revenue. So I think that we'll not go too far and answer you
componenttext: Well, that sort of a back end way to kind of give us real revenue guidance and there's a fair amount of variability in terms of mix as we know, how we experience over the last couple of years on revenue. So I think that we'll not go too far and answer your question. But certainly, I think that much of what we have in revenues are substantially the majority of it is already in backlog. If you look at how we talked about margins over the last couple of months going back to the third quarter call and then presentations since then, if you aggregate that all together, you're probably on a consolidated basis, somewhere in the plus 4% range. But where exactly that lands is just a tough call. There's just too many variables. So we feel good about the extent that our revenues are covered significantly by what's in the backlog. Yes, there is some book and burn. I think that as we said, the key variable there is the timing of new awards and how fast that comes in. But we feel really good about the prospects of those new awards. But it's a little early to judge how they're going to play, at what kind of a rate. So that's what we'll be watching as we go through the year.

headline: Fluor Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got you. I mean, maybe Biggs, on cash flow, it was a very good year on cash flow. I guess from here with -- you mentioned I think with -- or maybe in the K or in the comments, that the equipment business is one of the areas where we saw a little bit of we
componenttext: Got you. I mean, maybe Biggs, on cash flow, it was a very good year on cash flow. I guess from here with -- you mentioned I think with -- or maybe in the K or in the comments, that the equipment business is one of the areas where we saw a little bit of weakness. Do you feel like you monetized some of your assets in that business and short the balance sheet? What do you think the puts and takes are? And what's the appetite for that newly expanded share repurchase plan as well?

headline: Fluor Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, as far as the equipment business goes, we are expecting some pickup in 2016 particular as water [ph] projects transition towards constructions. So it has really come down, our mining activity came down year-over-year as a result of Afghanistan. But
componenttext: Well, as far as the equipment business goes, we are expecting some pickup in 2016 particular as water [ph] projects transition towards constructions. So it has really come down, our mining activity came down year-over-year as a result of Afghanistan. But most of that was really reflected as lower levels of equipment back to the end of 2014. So we'll see. But we think that's certainly there's prospects for that business to pick up as we support our own -- start our own projects and construction in 2016. In terms of capital deployment, as I said, initially we've got -- we have a healthy cash balance. We're really happy with how we generated cash last year and expect to do a really great job in generating cash this year. But we have some expenditures right in front of us in terms of the funding of the China fabrication joint venture. As I said in my comments, there's $500 million over the course of the year, just under $500 million that has to be funded. So over the very near term, I think that we have places, that we figure generate great returns over time to go invest in. Beyond that, our strategy remains the same as it has in the past, typically. We don't expect to preannounce any kind of a share repurchase program. What we expect to do is as we go through time, evaluate our excess capital as it's generated. What to see first if there's some high investment opportunity that will create a good return for shareholders. High investment return opportunity create the return for shareholders. And then if in the absence of that, we'll look to see if the repurchase shares just like we have in the past. But it's not a near-term analysis we had to go through. Because as I said, we've got some near-term opportunities for our cash. Commitments already made. We'll generate good cash flow in the future if we have that expectation, so we look forward to having to do that analysis going forward.

headline: Fluor Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: And next will be Michael Dudas with Sterne Agee.
componenttext: And next will be Michael Dudas with Sterne Agee.

headline: Fluor Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: David, your observations of Middle East, you mentioned about '99 [ph] when you were in Saudi at $17 oil. Given the geopolitics given where oil is today and some of history you've seen in the press and such, is that an area that can come back relatively qu
componenttext: David, your observations of Middle East, you mentioned about '99 [ph] when you were in Saudi at $17 oil. Given the geopolitics given where oil is today and some of history you've seen in the press and such, is that an area that can come back relatively quickly, the oil prices come back? And is that an area where you can see some spring board to some business in '17 and beyond? And '16 being more of a wait-and-see or are there still opportunities with low gas and chemical side that you can -- and the refining side that you can push through more opportunities in that oil?

headline: Fluor Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I'll go back to what I said, Michael. They haven't stopped spending, so there's still pretty robust slate of projects, but they're mostly refining and petrochemical programs, just like you're seeing here in the states. So I think there's near-term o
componenttext: Well, I'll go back to what I said, Michael. They haven't stopped spending, so there's still pretty robust slate of projects, but they're mostly refining and petrochemical programs, just like you're seeing here in the states. So I think there's near-term opportunities. My experience out there suggests that it depends on how much of a return on the oil price happens and when. But I've seen the turn on a dime in terms of what they want to do and I don't really want to call it a herd mentality. But they got these things pent up on their drawing board, they want to get them going and they can move them pretty rapidly. As I said, I don't think you're going to see the supply situation change dramatically until as we get into the mid part of the year. But once that glut kind of clears, I think you'll see commodity prices kind of stabilize if not rise as we get to the back end. But the other thing that I'd warn everybody about is when you think about the long-term nature of oil and gas developments, from exploratory well to production is a decade. So they're not thinking about spending today or tomorrow, they're thinking about spending today so that either their reserve base or their product mix or whatever is focused on that further longer view. And they're going to continue to fund those projects that satisfy that need. So 2 ways of answering your question. One, they can turn quick, I don't anticipate it in '16. But you're still going to see steady on the things that make sense.

headline: Fluor Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: And David, a follow-up on your question to one of the questions earlier, your Dallas presentation or something this morning. It seems -- is the -- given of what you see in your business and the diversity that you put forth especially in infrastructure, ma
componenttext: And David, a follow-up on your question to one of the questions earlier, your Dallas presentation or something this morning. It seems -- is the -- given of what you see in your business and the diversity that you put forth especially in infrastructure, manufacturing, life science, U.S. pipe opportunities, do you get the sense that your customer base and the diversity trend and even in Power is going to allow for some better activity from your U.S. customers, allowing you to get some more businesses as you move through 2016? Or is the concern about the economy that we read about in the press and here and we've seen on the TV all the time is more trouble some?

headline: Fluor Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think it's -- if I were to put a phrase on things, I'd say said steady as she goes. I mean, when you think about life sciences, pharmaceuticals, well and the taxing regimes in places Ireland and Singapore, and some of the other places around the world t
componenttext: I think it's -- if I were to put a phrase on things, I'd say said steady as she goes. I mean, when you think about life sciences, pharmaceuticals, well and the taxing regimes in places Ireland and Singapore, and some of the other places around the world that attracted those businesses, so it's not going to be a U.S.-based business by and large. I do still see the petrochemical resurgence in the United states continuing both in terms of additional crackers and the further downstream derivatives. So there is an example of where the U.S. will be there. The Westinghouse projects, kind of SKU us back towards almost that 50-50 or 60-40 kind of range in terms of U.S. versus non-U.S. business. But I still see more opportunities outside the United States than in the United States with the exception of maybe the infrastructure business.

headline: Fluor Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016

componenttext: And next will be Brian Konigsberg with Verticals Research Partners.

headline: Fluor Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Since no one's touched on it yet, maybe you can just address the issues on the Brunswick Power project and just maybe more specifically, you're saying mechanical activities are done, I expected it to be completely finished by spring. But what risk activit
componenttext: Since no one's touched on it yet, maybe you can just address the issues on the Brunswick Power project and just maybe more specifically, you're saying mechanical activities are done, I expected it to be completely finished by spring. But what risk activities might be left between now and then that we might be should be concerned about or not.

headline: Fluor Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good question. We're basically done in the final throes. The biggest issues is startup condition where you introduce lube oil and you recycle lube oil, and you make that change and the supplier's program in what we were told by the customers that it took
componenttext: Good question. We're basically done in the final throes. The biggest issues is startup condition where you introduce lube oil and you recycle lube oil, and you make that change and the supplier's program in what we were told by the customers that it took 45 days and it took us 90. So there in lies the majority and it took us past the end of the third quarter, obviously, and that was certainly not anticipated. But we're all but done in terms of that project. I said in the last call that we had it under control and there were no losses. So I'm not going to say it again, but we're ready to start this thing up. So I don't really anticipate anything that we haven't anticipated will happen now.

headline: Fluor Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got it. And just secondly, you've made some comments on pricing, you are seeing some pressure. It doesn't seem like it's overwhelming, but maybe just talk about what the assumptions are for 2016, and maybe not just in oil and gas but what you're seeing ac
componenttext: Got it. And just secondly, you've made some comments on pricing, you are seeing some pressure. It doesn't seem like it's overwhelming, but maybe just talk about what the assumptions are for 2016, and maybe not just in oil and gas but what you're seeing across Power and Infrastructure, and some of the other businesses that are actually gaining a little momentum is there becoming increasingly competitive given that oil and gas is falling or becoming a little weaker.

headline: Fluor Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I think the Power market is still a pretty tough market and will be for some time. I would never categorize it as easy. These are -- there's a lot of competitors and they like to feed their warehouse too. And depending on how hungry they are is how
componenttext: Well, I think the Power market is still a pretty tough market and will be for some time. I would never categorize it as easy. These are -- there's a lot of competitors and they like to feed their warehouse too. And depending on how hungry they are is how they act in terms of pricing. So we still see that as pretty tough market. But again, either the way we're -- the way we're doing work applies to Power just like it applies to some of the other businesses. So we're kind of changing the game a little bit and I think we've got a competitive offering. Infrastructure is a little bit the same way, but we're starting to see some of these things come to fruition and we're winning. And we're winning in things that we already know how to do, roads and light rail, and we're winning with acceptable margins with our partner. So I feel reasonably okay there. The other businesses are doing quite fine. We talked a lot about oil and gas, our ability and the quality of the margin and the backlog that I spoke off, I think is testament to changing the model of how we deliver, which makes us more competitive in the marketplace. Our Government business has done quite well. We haven't talked about that when we went to Idaho and I really, really huge wind -- win for us and something we're really pleased with, which again, if you think about it, that adds and with the Stork acquisition, it adds to that non-commodity piece of our business, which should surprise -- provide some stability in earnings over the longer term. Those are big long 3 to 5-year kind of contracts. So again, going back to part of my comment to Jamie, that also gives us confidence in our ability to end '16 and start '17 with a pretty robust capability in terms of earnings potential. So this is hard business and it's always competitive. It's never easy in terms of what our competition confronts us with or what our client expectations are. And I'm just really proud of our organization to how we respond to that and how we've responded as an organization to a new way of doing business, the results and better margin performance across the board.

headline: Fluor Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just to summarize though, I mean, it sounds like you're not assuming any -- anything out of the norm relative to the last couple of years form pricing within the guidance for '16. Is that a fair statement?
componenttext: Just to summarize though, I mean, it sounds like you're not assuming any -- anything out of the norm relative to the last couple of years form pricing within the guidance for '16. Is that a fair statement?

componenttext: No. That's a fair statement. We're seeing -- we are seeing some of our competitors in a little bit of dark spreads, which you worry about in terms of what are they going to do next. But we feel good about what we're pursuing and how we're pursuing it and whom we're pursuing it for, if that makes sense.

headline: Fluor Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, if you look at the 3 crackers in the U.S. we're working on now, CPChem are well underway in construction and on the intended schedules that were there in terms of costs, we're right on target. Is the one that's a little bit behind in terms of schedu
componenttext: Well, if you look at the 3 crackers in the U.S. we're working on now, CPChem are well underway in construction and on the intended schedules that were there in terms of costs, we're right on target. Is the one that's a little bit behind in terms of schedule. We're in the field but really, only in the civil side of the business and feel pretty good about where we are there. So I would say that they're progressing like we planned and progressing quite nicely for those customers.

headline: Fluor Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016

componenttext: Great. And then on the Power segment, can you update on the filing timeline and investments that you put into a new scale?

headline: Fluor Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, as we said in the prepared -- I think in Biggs' prepared remarks, really about $80 million to $90 million spend this year, leading up to the submittal of the design certification towards the -- first or middle of the third quarter. We've had a great
componenttext: Yes, as we said in the prepared -- I think in Biggs' prepared remarks, really about $80 million to $90 million spend this year, leading up to the submittal of the design certification towards the -- first or middle of the third quarter. We've had a great conversations with the DOE and the NRC about their preparedness to review that submittal. We feel good about the fact that our first customer has gotten an agreement with the DOE for a site for the first one in Idaho, and just the fact that we won the Idaho project, I think strengthens our ability to deliver on that. So we're on target. We feel good about what we're going to submit. We feel good about the NRC's readiness to do that review. And we think that opens the door for future investment in NuScale from outside of Fluor.

headline: Fluor Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016

componenttext: And the next question will come from Andrew Oben with Bank of America, Merryl Lynch.

componenttext: Great.

headline: Fluor Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I know. So just a question of as taking a sort of 40,000-foot view. So you use '90s [ph] as a reference to what's happening in the oil and gas cycle. So lot of discussions we're having with clients, do you think it's more like the '90s or it's more l
componenttext: Yes. I know. So just a question of as taking a sort of 40,000-foot view. So you use '90s [ph] as a reference to what's happening in the oil and gas cycle. So lot of discussions we're having with clients, do you think it's more like the '90s or it's more like the '80s? And what do you think is the difference or implied difference is in strategy if it's more like the '80s?

headline: Fluor Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I think the one thing that's not being spoken of is the demand growth in this discussion. And when you look at those demand growth, we're still looking at a million barrels a day kind of growth in the midterm, I would say. So when you think about so
componenttext: Well, I think the one thing that's not being spoken of is the demand growth in this discussion. And when you look at those demand growth, we're still looking at a million barrels a day kind of growth in the midterm, I would say. So when you think about some of the production that's going to naturally come off due to depletion curves, you look at -- I guess, the Saudi's and the Russians kind of put up for a lack of a better term, a ceiling on production. You can see where that glut's going to clear pretty quickly. I think what's different this time is in a lot of these producing countries, their cost base has gone up because of the social programs. So I think they're going to do what they can to turn this more quickly than maybe would have taken place when you -- even if you go back into the '70s and what the embargo did. So I'm not sure you can actually do a comparison to the '90s. Not sure you can do a comparison to the '70s or even if you go back into the early 2000's when pricing went down. I just think it's a different marker. And I'll give you an example. This is the first time in my career where when the sabers rattle between anybody in the Middle East that threatens the straights of our, and I'm speaking specifically between the Saudi's and the Iranians which obviously, was in the press. The oil price didn't spike by $10 a barrel the next day, and in fact, this time, it went down. So I would argue that the fundamentals are significantly different today in terms of who's producing and how much they're producing, and the change and the flow of those products over the last decade. More gas, more LNG, LNG glut right now. Oil is there, coal is bad. I mean, I just think that there's a lot of issues that are different in this cycle than they were in the past. But I think the one thing that's going to drive may be a quicker recovery than some of the historical times is the need for a cost per barrel to satisfy the social need to some of these producers.

headline: Fluor Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you for such a great answer. Just a follow-up. In talking to a lot of corporates we're hearing that it's not in the price decline per se, but it's also the price volatility that's inhabiting their ability to plan CapEx. In your conversations with yo
componenttext: Thank you for such a great answer. Just a follow-up. In talking to a lot of corporates we're hearing that it's not in the price decline per se, but it's also the price volatility that's inhabiting their ability to plan CapEx. In your conversations with your customers, how long -- how much of a stability do we need to see in oil prices to get them comfortable in putting plants out? Do you think it's 1 month? Do think it's 3 months? What are you hearing?

headline: Fluor Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I think they're already on a new level. I think that -- and I've said this before, I think many of them would say that they were drunk on $100 oil, my term, don't tell them I said that. And probably wouldn't have made some of the funding decisions t
componenttext: Well, I think they're already on a new level. I think that -- and I've said this before, I think many of them would say that they were drunk on $100 oil, my term, don't tell them I said that. And probably wouldn't have made some of the funding decisions that they made if they didn't -- in their backroom believe that $100 oil was there to stay. So I think in their backrooms now, they are thinking $40, $50 kind of range is the new norm and we have to plan on that basis. And we're already seeing them use a more reasonable number. I remember back in the day, when they used to plan on '14. It was the kind of the litmus test for capital spend. So it'll morph and change, but I think there's a huge wake-up call that $100 isn't something that's there forever. But I also remember everybody saying the sky would fall and the world would end if it ever went above $100. That didn't happen either. So I think what we're hearing from our customers is there's kind of a new norm, and somewhere between $40 and $70 is probably the kind of the sweet spot for the longer-term.

headline: Fluor Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from Tahira Afzal with KeyBanc.
componenttext: And our next question comes from Tahira Afzal with KeyBanc.

headline: Fluor Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016

componenttext: First question is David, you commented earlier on aggregate backlog potentially being flat as possible this year. Are there any segments in particular where you're more comfortable saying that than others?

headline: Fluor Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think I provided a little bit of color there. I mean there's some growth opportunities in all of our businesses to a varying degree without -- I would take mining out of that. There's really not any intended new awards in there and we're finishing a cou
componenttext: I think I provided a little bit of color there. I mean there's some growth opportunities in all of our businesses to a varying degree without -- I would take mining out of that. There's really not any intended new awards in there and we're finishing a couple of projects. So I continue I&I in terms of backlog drop because mining was such a huge piece of that. But you think -- I mean, we're -- $44 billion in backlog is almost an all-time high. And we have the ability or we stay -- we have the ability to stay at that level. I mean that speaks volumes of how powerful this company is in terms of satisfying customers and expanding our opportunity. So again, I wouldn't point to anyone other than mining that's a bit of a challenge. Each of our groups has -- have opportunities to grow.

headline: Fluor Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: And David, kind of your optimist in your upbeat note on oil and gas, could you update your mix, would you say that market share gains wise, you stand pretty well with the caveat, is that also playing into your outlook?
componenttext: And David, kind of your optimist in your upbeat note on oil and gas, could you update your mix, would you say that market share gains wise, you stand pretty well with the caveat, is that also playing into your outlook?

headline: Fluor Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: We don't really look at it in those terms. I mean market share in this business is really a magic number. I mean, it's -- you got to really understand what goes into that total number to see what market share is. But what we have seen is a combination of
componenttext: We don't really look at it in those terms. I mean market share in this business is really a magic number. I mean, it's -- you got to really understand what goes into that total number to see what market share is. But what we have seen is a combination of the integrated solutions offering that includes fabrication and includes supply chain, includes a resurge in our direct hire construction capabilities is proving very effective with our customers. And I think the fact that we continue to pull in billions of dollars every quarter in on oil and gas and obviously, the other things that we do is a testimony to the customers acceptance of our new way of doing business.

headline: Fluor Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: And you can add to that our ability to design the product differently.
componenttext: And you can add to that our ability to design the product differently.

headline: Fluor Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: But I think that our ability to continue to create or have a positive cash flow in some difficult markets is another testament to the strength of this company and what we can actually deliver. I mean, it provides us with the ability to go places when othe
componenttext: But I think that our ability to continue to create or have a positive cash flow in some difficult markets is another testament to the strength of this company and what we can actually deliver. I mean, it provides us with the ability to go places when others can't. I mean, I go back to what Buffet says, and I'm not signaling anymore acquisitions. But Warren Buffett says, that he's nervous when people are greedy and he's greedy when people are nervous. Well, right now people are nervous and we've got the powder to deal with the things we need to deal with.

headline: Fluor Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got it. Makes sense, David. I just have a brief, last question. If I look at what's making a lot of these projects economical again on the oil and gas side is clearly, the costs have come down for the project. Do you think you are at a point where your ba
componenttext: Got it. Makes sense, David. I just have a brief, last question. If I look at what's making a lot of these projects economical again on the oil and gas side is clearly, the costs have come down for the project. Do you think you are at a point where your back bookings on an annualized basis are down considerably? So would it be fair to say that the scope at this point, even if it's with you it's kind of taken into consideration when you're talking about potentially backlog even in that segment being potentially flat at some point?

headline: Fluor Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I think it's puts and takes it is time. As Biggs said earlier, when you think about revenue is all timing of projects and where they are in their cycle. But I think being -- having the kind of backlog where we our is interesting, but I would point y
componenttext: Well, I think it's puts and takes it is time. As Biggs said earlier, when you think about revenue is all timing of projects and where they are in their cycle. But I think being -- having the kind of backlog where we our is interesting, but I would point you back to maybe 4 years ago when it was half that. So I think the way we position the company and the way we kind of changed our model, when the markets move, and they will, I think we're in an outstanding position to take advantage of that and we have significant upside potential. But I just think that, that's further out in time than -- '16, '17. But we're ready and I'm really pleased with the way the organizations responded to this opportunity.

headline: Fluor Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016

componenttext: That does conclude the question-and-answer session. I'll now turn the conference back over to you for any additional or closing remarks.

headline: Fluor Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you very much, operator, and thanks to all of you for participating today. As I said in my opening remarks, we do expect commodity prices to stay low and will continue to drive customers decisions. But I do know that they're going to continue to spe
componenttext: Thank you very much, operator, and thanks to all of you for participating today. As I said in my opening remarks, we do expect commodity prices to stay low and will continue to drive customers decisions. But I do know that they're going to continue to spend and focus on these high-quality projects that we have in our sites. As I've mentioned, our integrated solutions approach has met the demand in terms of our customers need for capital-efficient projects and we'll continue to work on that and hopefully continue to drive down those costs. This is not a demand that will subside when commodity prices begin to improve. To that end, the changes we've made in our business model have prepared us for the next cycle. And that next cycle will come. We've been through this. I've been in this business for a long time and what is now down will go up again. The evolution of our offerings, I think has provided us with robust cash flow generation as I mentioned earlier, and this strengthens our balance sheet and our ability to continue to operate. I think our cost management discipline also gives us an advantage and an opportunity to be more successful in the future. Not to say that '16 is going to be an easy year. It's going to be a difficult year. But I think there's great opportunity as we go through this as we continue to deliver for our shareholders. With that, I greatly appreciate your interest in our company and the confidence that you provide us. And I wish you all a good day.

headline: Fluor Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, thank you. And that does conclude today's conference call. We, do thank you for your participation today.
componenttext: Well, thank you. And that does conclude today's conference call. We, do thank you for your participation today.

headline: Fluor Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good afternoon, and welcome to Fluor Corporation's Fourth Quarter and Year-end 2015 Conference Call. Today's call is being recorded. [Operator Instructions] A replay of today's conference call will be available at approximately 8:30 p.m. Eastern Time toda
componenttext:
Good afternoon, and welcome to Fluor Corporation's Fourth Quarter and Year-end 2015 Conference Call. Today's call is being recorded. [Operator Instructions] A replay of today's conference call will be available at approximately 8:30 p.m. Eastern Time today, accessible on Fluor's website at www.fluor.com. The web replay will be available for 30 days. A telephone replay will also be available through 7:30 p.m. Eastern Time on February 24, at the following telephone number, (888) 203-1112. The passcode of 5904252 will be required. 
At this time, for opening remarks, I would like to turn the call over to Geoff Telfer, Senior Vice President of Investor Relations. Please go ahead, Mr. Telfer.

headline: Fluor Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Justin, and welcome to Fluor's Fourth Quarter 2015 Conference Call. With us today are David Seaton, Fluor's Chairman and Chief Executive Officer; and Biggs Porter, Fluor's Chief Financial Officer. Our earnings announcement was released this a
componenttext:
Thank you, Justin, and welcome to Fluor's Fourth Quarter 2015 Conference Call. With us today are David Seaton, Fluor's Chairman and Chief Executive Officer; and Biggs Porter, Fluor's Chief Financial Officer. 
Our earnings announcement was released this afternoon after market close, and we have posted a slide presentation on our website, which we'll reference while making prepared remarks. But before getting started, I'd like to refer you to our Safe Harbor note regarding forward-looking statements, which is summarized on Slide 2. 
During today's call and slide presentation, we'll be making forward-looking statements, which reflect our current analysis of existing trends and information. However, there is an inherent risk that actual results could differ materially. You can find a discussion of our risk factors, which could potentially contribute to such differences in the company's Form 10-K, which was filed earlier today. 
During today's call, we may also discuss certain non-GAAP financial measures. Reconciliations of these amounts with the comparable GAAP measures are reflected in our earnings release and posted in the Investor Relations section of our website at investors.fluor.com. 
Now I'll turn the call over to David Seaton, Fluor's Chairman and CEO. David?

headline: Fluor Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Jeff. Good afternoon, everyone, and thank you for joining us. On today's call, we'll review our fourth quarter and full year of 2015 as well as discuss our outlook for 2016. Before we talk about our fourth quarter and full year results, I do want
componenttext:
Thanks, Jeff. Good afternoon, everyone, and thank you for joining us. On today's call, we'll review our fourth quarter and full year of 2015 as well as discuss our outlook for 2016. Before we talk about our fourth quarter and full year results, I do want to spend a few minutes to share my perspective on the markets we serve. 
Global economic growth continues to be weak and commodity prices remain low. We expect economic growth for the year to be similar of the past few years, yet we also expect commodity prices to stabilize during this year and perhaps even begin to improve in the last part of the year. The lower commodity prices obviously, continue to impact our customers' cash flows and therefore, their ability to fund certain projects at the same pace that they've done previously. 
Many of our customers have already announced significant reductions in their capital expenditure budgets for 2016. However, Fluor serves a diverse portfolio of industries and regions. This provides the company opportunities even in difficult market environments. While low oil prices may delay some Oil & Gas projects, Fluor is focused on our clients and their spending priorities. 
As I've mentioned in the past, we continue to see the FID on large greenfield LNG facilities to move to the right as clients focus on opportunities to improve capital efficiency. By that extension, it's important to note that we do not anticipate any material contributions from LNG projects during 2016. Our Power business should experience strong growth this year with the Westinghouse projects now fully transitioned plus the business has experienced an uptick in gas-related projects. 
Our government and infrastructure markets are also experiencing growth with key recent wins, including the $1.4 billion nuclear cleanup project in Idaho and the Arizona Loop 202 project. We also expect to hear shortly the outcome of our bid to build the 16-mile Purple Line light rail project in Maryland. We continue to implement our integrated solution strategy. Our strategy focuses on delivering the full spectrum of capital efficient solutions for our customers. 
We've taken significant steps in 2015 to broaden our offering, including expanding our global fabrication footprint with the announcement of the COOEC joint venture in China and extending our position in the construction and maintenance markets through the Westinghouse Nuclear Awards and our upcoming acquisition Stork. While we're talking about fabrication investments and historic acquisition, let me give you an update on the closing status. Our JV with COOEC and the Zhuhai fabrication yard continues to progress. We're receiving final approvals now and expect to make our first payment in the next few months. 
Back in December, we announced the intent to acquire Stork, a maintenance and modification and asset integrity company based in The Netherlands. Stork enhances not only our current offering, but creates tremendous opportunity to leverage our combined capabilities and brands across a broad spectrum of opportunities. We anticipate this transaction to also close in the next few months. 
While we expect 2016 to be another challenging year, our focus will be on the things that we can control. Now let's look at our 2015 full year results beginning with Slide 5 -- Slide 3. Excluding a pretax nonoperating pension settlement expense of $240 million, net earnings attributable to Fluor from continuing operations were $571 million or $3.89 per diluted share compared with $715 million or $4.48 per diluted share a year ago. 
Consolidated segment profit for 2015 was $1 billion, which compares to $1.3 billion a year ago. Despite volatile oil prices, our Oil & Gas segment performed very well during the year, contributing $764 million in segment profit, a 14% increase over 2014. However, this increase was offset by the decline in other segments. Segment profits -- profit margins were 5.7%, which compares with 5.9% a year ago. 
Consolidated 2015 revenue was $18.1 billion, down from $21.5 billion a year ago. Full year new awards were $21.8 billion, including $11 billion in Oil & Gas, $6 billion in Power, $3.2 billion in Industrial and Infrastructure and $1.4 billion in Government. Consolidated backlog for the year ended -- ending was $44.7 billion, up 5% from $42.5 billion a year ago. Our clients have not given any indication that they intend to cancel any ongoing projects with us. 
Turning to Slide 4. The Oil & Gas segment got $2.1 billion in new awards, including 2 Pemex refining projects in Mexico. Ending backlog for that segment was $28.8 billion, which compares to $28.5 billion in 2014. Fourth quarter new awards in industrial and infrastructure were $302 million. We closed the year with a backlog of $5.6 billion compared to $7.2 billion at the end of 2014, which reflects the reduced Mining & Metals new award activity. 
The Government group posted fourth quarter new awards of $352 million, and they're ending backlog in 2015 was $3.6 billion. Turning to Slide 5 in the Power segment. Fourth quarter new awards of $5.1 billion, including award for 2 reimbursable contracts with Westinghouse Electric Company to manage the construction workforce at 2 nuclear power plants in Georgia and South Carolina. Ending backlog for 2015 was $6.8 billion, which compares to $2.1 billion a year ago. 
Segment profit for the fourth quarter was impacted by a $31 million charge related to a gas Fluor Power facility in Brunswick County, Virginia. This was primarily related to commissioning, taking longer than expected due to changes and challenges associated with the installation of the gas turbines that extended past the third quarter. This project has reached mechanical completion, and we anticipate turning this project over to the customer in the spring. 
With that, now I'll turn the call over to Biggs to review some of the details of our operating performance and the corporate financial metrics for the quarter. Biggs?

headline: Fluor Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, David, and good afternoon, everyone. Please turn to Slide 6 of the presentation. I'll start by providing some additional comments on our fourth quarter performance then move to the balance sheet. Revenue for the quarter was $4.4 billion, which c
componenttext:
Thanks, David, and good afternoon, everyone. Please turn to Slide 6 of the presentation. I'll start by providing some additional comments on our fourth quarter performance then move to the balance sheet. 
Revenue for the quarter was $4.4 billion, which compares to $5.5 billion a year ago. All segments reported slight year-over-year reductions, with the exception of industrial infrastructure, which experienced a 41% decline mainly due to the continued reduction in mining activity. Excluding the pension settlement expense of $231 million, or $1.04 per diluted share in the quarter, EPS from continuing operations for the fourth quarter was $0.68 compared to $1.41 a year ago. 
Including pension settlement expenses, the company reported a loss of $51 million or $0.36 per diluted share. This quarter's EPS was negatively impacted by approximately $0.21 per share due to the combined effect of the $31 million charge on the Brunswick Power project and the higher-than-expected tax rate due to losses in 2 foreign subsidiaries that we weren't able to benefit for U.S. tax purposes. These tax effects converse in the future. 
Over the course of the year, we received a few questions about the impact of foreign exchange rates on the P&L. Looking at the impact of FX on a quarterly basis, there is very little variation. However, when you look at FX from a yearly impact, 2015 versus 2014, using average rates of both periods, there is a negative impact to EPS of approximately $0.20. Corporate G&A expenses in the fourth quarter was $54 million compared to $53 million a year ago. 
Shifting to the balance sheet. Fluor's financial position remains very strong, with cash plus current and noncurrent marketable securities totaling $2.4 billion, flat with a year ago. In 2015 the company generated $849 million in cash flow from operating activities compared to $643 million in 2014. The company also returned $635 million in cash to shareholders through share repurchases and dividends. 
In the first quarter 2015 as you recall, we also settled a claim for dispute operations of $306 million. Absent that, cash flow from operations would be even stronger. The previously announced $1 billion share repurchase program was completed in the fourth quarter of 2014 through the end of 2015. For the year, we repurchased 10,105,000 shares. On February 4, 2016, the Board of Directors increased our outstanding share repurchase reauthorization by 10 million shares. However, although our cash position is strong at year-end, everyone should keep in mind that we have existing near-term commitments for our cash. 
Moving to Slide 7. Fluor's consolidated backlog at year-end was $44.7 billion. The percentage of fixed price contracts in our overall backlog was 22% at quarter end, and the mix by geography was 41% U.S. and 59% non-U.S. For the year, backlog was negatively impacted by about $3 billion as a result of the strong dollar. 
I will conclude my remarks by commenting on our guidance for 2016, which is on Slide 8. We are maintaining our guidance for 2016 at $3.50 to $4 per share. Our guidance for 2016 also assumed G&A expense in the range of $190 million to $200 million and a tax rate of 33% to 35%. Other expectations for 2016 include NuScale expenses of approximately $90 million as we get to DCA submittal later this year, capital expenditures of approximately $300 million and our payments to fund our joint venture with COOEC of $350 million in the first half and $140 million in the third quarter of this year. Our guidance does not include any benefit related to our acquisition of Stork nor any transaction and integration-related cost. This transaction is expected to close as early as March. Our guidance reflects an expectation of gradual quarterly improvement in 2016. 
With that operator, we're ready to take questions.

headline: Fluor Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
