componenttext: And we'll take our next question with Chad Dillard with Deutsche Bank.

headline: Fluor Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: So you've won a pretty decent amount of infrastructure work so far. So I just be curious to hear about what you're seeing going forward, and do you think you have enough capacity to absorb the additional infrastructure work? And do you think you'll be abl
componenttext: So you've won a pretty decent amount of infrastructure work so far. So I just be curious to hear about what you're seeing going forward, and do you think you have enough capacity to absorb the additional infrastructure work? And do you think you'll be able to pull other underutilized individuals from the rest of your -- from the rest of the area to help them out?

headline: Fluor Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Absolutely. I don't think we have any issues with capacity frankly, in any of the markets that we serve. There are pieces that we want to improve and skills sets that we need to go get. But when you look at -- we just finished and actually, I participated
componenttext: Absolutely. I don't think we have any issues with capacity frankly, in any of the markets that we serve. There are pieces that we want to improve and skills sets that we need to go get. But when you look at -- we just finished and actually, I participated in the ribbon-cutting of the Denver Light Rail project last week or 2 weeks ago. And many of those people are headed to the Purple Line in Maryland. So we feel pretty good about our place in the infrastructure market. And frankly speaking, we see that as one of the growth areas. As you mentioned, we've been very successful this year. But I'd point you to last year where we were very unsuccessful. By and large, because of some predatory pricing by the competition. So not only do we see good opportunity, but we also have good solid projects in terms of backlog margin as we burn that and as we execute. So I'm pretty bullish on the infrastructure market and as I said in the previous question and the prepared remarks, the fact that we can be competitive in an open procurement, more than 200 kind of million dollar project, I think bodes well for that group.

headline: Fluor Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great. And then with your new guidance, so at the midpoint, is what you have in the backlog currently enough to get you there? Or do you need to win more work?
componenttext: Great. And then with your new guidance, so at the midpoint, is what you have in the backlog currently enough to get you there? Or do you need to win more work?

componenttext: Well, we always need to win new work. I mean, I'm not going to get into what percentage of backlog is there, but we always need to book -- we always need to win new work for book and burn and hit any of the numbers, any of the years, any of the quarters. And there's nobody in the market space, any different.

headline: Fluor Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: I wanted to focus on the Industrial and Infrastructure segment for a second. So if you're looking at smaller infrastructure projects, does it change the way you bid for these projects? Does it change your risk profile and eventually, what does this mean f
componenttext: I wanted to focus on the Industrial and Infrastructure segment for a second. So if you're looking at smaller infrastructure projects, does it change the way you bid for these projects? Does it change your risk profile and eventually, what does this mean for margins?

headline: Fluor Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: No. It doesn't. Our approach to bidding projects and how we look at risk has not changed and will not change in the market conditions -- even in the market conditions we find ourselves in. So we're going to be very, very diligent in terms of that. So I th
componenttext: No. It doesn't. Our approach to bidding projects and how we look at risk has not changed and will not change in the market conditions -- even in the market conditions we find ourselves in. So we're going to be very, very diligent in terms of that. So I think the kind of margin that we've seen in some of the bigger projects, we're going to continue to see in these smaller projects. So really no change at all in terms of how we bid or aggressiveness therefore.

headline: Fluor Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then sort of on a related note. You seemed hopeful about some of the benefits from FAST act coming through. In a -- let's say, an optimistic scenario, how do you see that playing out? And what would be the time line if it does in fact, go throug
componenttext: Okay. And then sort of on a related note. You seemed hopeful about some of the benefits from FAST act coming through. In a -- let's say, an optimistic scenario, how do you see that playing out? And what would be the time line if it does in fact, go through?

headline: Fluor Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I think -- there's 2 pieces to it, right? And I think -- well actually, 3 pieces. The first piece is I think it gives the state's confident, I'm talking about just specifically U.S. it gives the states confidence to push some of these things through
componenttext: Well, I think -- there's 2 pieces to it, right? And I think -- well actually, 3 pieces. The first piece is I think it gives the state's confident, I'm talking about just specifically U.S. it gives the states confidence to push some of these things through that there will be some federal funding associated with what they've got to do. Every state that we really focus on has significant legislation on -- in the works, I'll say. This support a very large amount of projects to come to fruition. The other piece of it is going to be some of these shovel-ready projects in fixing potholes to everything else. And we're not really going to focus on that. But every one of these programs at these states are looking at, has significant bridge work, have significant toll road opportunities, which the public-private partnership, which is the last piece are going to have to play a role. Now one of the things that some of the states need to do is they need to make it legal to do public-private partnerships for infrastructure programs. Not every state has that kind of laws in the books that allows it. But I think that we're finally at a point where the deterioration of the infrastructure in the United States is to a point where we got to do something. This port access project is just the first piece of the Charleston Port expansion. So winning this one puts us in a good position to get the next one. But there's lots and lots of programs that we're going to have access to and I'm really pretty bullish on that market. But again, I'm not sure it's going to be this year that we're going to see significantly new awards because these projects take a long time to put together. And I'll point to the Eagle P3 project in Denver. That project started in discussion in 2003. And we just opened it. So there's a long tail to these things. But they've got a good earnings stream and they're on the road for a long period of time. When you look at the Eagle P3, we've got a 28-year maintenance contract that started when we opened it last week. So again, it goes to another question that was asked. When you look at infrastructure, it builds a good base over the longer term that we could use to grow from.

headline: Fluor Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. That's very helpful and just kind of wrapping up the questions on the segment. Biggs, is there a way that you can help us think through the backlog through -- I mean new awards and backlog burn in the segment now that the nuclear projects are in the
componenttext: Okay. That's very helpful and just kind of wrapping up the questions on the segment. Biggs, is there a way that you can help us think through the backlog through -- I mean new awards and backlog burn in the segment now that the nuclear projects are in there as well?

headline: Fluor Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well the -- I mean, we expect the nuclear projects themselves, that one is a little simpler and more straight forward probably because it -- we hit the ground besides the fact that it took us a month or so to get some employees up. Other than that, those
componenttext: Well the -- I mean, we expect the nuclear projects themselves, that one is a little simpler and more straight forward probably because it -- we hit the ground besides the fact that it took us a month or so to get some employees up. Other than that, those projects kind of hit the ground running because they're already underway. So there's a $5 billion award over roughly 5 years, you've got that 20% burning each year. So it was just in rough terms that's how you look at the burn within the Industrial, Infrastructure and Power segment being affected by those awards. This is interesting because it is interesting book and burn, but it still brings the average burn rate down because it's a 5-year project. Other than that, I think that there's no other rule or novelties to point out. A question that's one thing that I don't know that we read cash for everybody was a historical backlog numbers to -- so they could see historical book and bird would be, so let me go back and look at that and see if there's a way to help you on it.

headline: Fluor Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: A lot of the resources are in the company and we have the ability to move people around to different projects. So I don't think from a leadership perspective it's -- we really have an issue. We're always going to bring people in with the skills that we ne
componenttext: A lot of the resources are in the company and we have the ability to move people around to different projects. So I don't think from a leadership perspective it's -- we really have an issue. We're always going to bring people in with the skills that we need. When you look at what's in front of us, obviously, white rail is going to be so we're going to need rail expertise as I mentioned, there's going to be a lot of bridge works so we're going to need some bridge expertise. So I feel pretty good in be able to bring those folks on as necessary. And we'll clear the add -- if you added to that. But I don't see a capacity issue. And we've added -- when you think about the resources from the 2 nukes in Stork, we're over 60,000 employees now. And I still believe we're the employer of choice given our ability to retain people. So I think that we can move -- we're going to reallocate resources around the globe. I think this first model is working in showing that we don't need to hire and fire like the normal cycles that dictated in the past. I'd point to Houston as an example. There's been a size at least in the last little while as high as 4,800 people. And it's around 2,800 people now and it has been for 2.5 years -- 3 years. And we don't expect it to drop much more than that. So again, some of the things he done to perfect the dispersed execution model I think gives us a lot more stability in the -- across the portfolio, but it also shows that when we need to turn the crank, we can bring in the people we need almost regardless of how big we need to be.

componenttext: No. I don't think so. And I've said this in previous discussions with some of you. I lived in Saudi Arabia in the '90s. And I remember 1997, oil was $17 a barrel, up from $11. And even though oil is in the places towards a bit more difficult to get to may be then, they were still -- Saudi Aramco was still spending $30 billion a year, right? So they're still going to spend at $40 and $50 and $60. And they don't need to get back in most cases to the peak for them to be more profitable. So I don't think we need to retool any more than we've already we tooled because I think that things that we have done to become more competitive and satisfy that capital efficiency needed by our customers puts us in a position to be extremely robust and profitable as we go into the next wave.

componenttext: Yes, I mean, I -- it's not a high revenue type company. I mean, it's basically service revenue people. Sir not going to see a huge bump in revenue. But I think we'll see some good pumps in profitability. The short answer is absolutely, we're already seeing opportunities that arise at maybe we didn't have access to before. I think that the fact that Stork is owned by a Fluor now gives customers confident that they're there for the longer-term. There might have been some question before in terms of their viability. The -- so we're seeing great response from the customers in terms of their interest in hiring Stork. And we're in some markets where Fluor physically wasn't present that helps Fluor in those Strube traffic regions. There's lots of headroom I believe in the West those when we look at the install capital days the gold coast, it's a huge number of facilities and assets that need to be managed and need to be maintenance and modification shutdown turnaround those kinds of things that make Fluor very attractive in terms of their delivery model. So I think that we just kind of scratch the surface and I think there's great growth opportunity for that segment of the business.

But are there longer-term our bigger picture implications from this if other companies start doing more of it? Is it something that affects competition later on in the project lifecycle? Does it affect your visibility? I don't know if this is a trend you're watching, but I thought I'd ask about it.

headline: Fluor Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, it's a good question. We've seen this before. And we certainly see it now. I would argue that it's a huge mistake because typically, those people don't do the types of services that we do. We've got real examples where that has happened in terms of FE
componenttext: No, it's a good question. We've seen this before. And we certainly see it now. I would argue that it's a huge mistake because typically, those people don't do the types of services that we do. We've got real examples where that has happened in terms of FEED projects in Oil & Gas in previous cycles. And not that long ago where they had people available so they said, well, let's let them do the FEED. And then they came to us to actually redo the FEED because the answer that they got was too expensive and not the right schedule. So I -- they've probably don't like to hear me say that. But we're really good at those kinds of things. And there really good at producing product. And we're better positioned -- our industry is better positioned to do those kinds of things. But they've got pressures that they've got to deal with in terms of deployment. In some cases, they can't ebb and flow like a company like ours can. And we understand that. And will be there to help them when they need it.

headline: Fluor Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, operator, and thanks to all of you for participating today. As I said in the opening remarks and certainly in the Q&A, we continue to see that low commodity prices are driving customers to extend projects and delay FID decisions based on cash f
componenttext:
Thank you, operator, and thanks to all of you for participating today. As I said in the opening remarks and certainly in the Q&A, we continue to see that low commodity prices are driving customers to extend projects and delay FID decisions based on cash flow. This, I think, coupled with a little bit slower pace associated with some of the larger projects we've won over the past couple of years. In the long, O&M contracts, we recently put into place and infrastructure and others, have a slower burn might provide I think a more stable revenue trajectory. 
The revised 2016 guidance range reflects I think this reality. While our capital structure is sound and our cash flow generation remains robust, we remain disciplined in how we use our cash and we'll continue to do so as we look at lowering our cost of business and costs associated with it. Finally, we continue to invest for the long-term. As you've seen with our recent investments in the fab yard and certainly Stork, it positions our company to not only take care or capture market share in the traditional markets, but it also allows us to show growth in some of the longer-term aspects of our business. 
And with that, we greatly appreciate your interest in Fluor and your confidence in our company. Thank you, and have a good evening.

Please go ahead, Mr. Telfer.

headline: Fluor Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Shannon, and welcome to Fluor's First Quarter 2016 Conference Call. With us today are David Seaton, Fluor's Chairman and Chief Executive Officer; and Biggs Porter, Fluor's Chief Financial Officer. Our earnings announcement was released this a
componenttext:
Thank you, Shannon, and welcome to Fluor's First Quarter 2016 Conference Call. With us today are David Seaton, Fluor's Chairman and Chief Executive Officer; and Biggs Porter, Fluor's Chief Financial Officer. 
Our earnings announcement was released this afternoon after market close, and we have posted a slide presentation on our website, which we'll reference while making prepared remarks. But before getting started, I'd like to refer you to our Safe Harbor note regarding forward-looking statements, which is summarized on Slide 2. 
During today's call and slide presentation, we will be making forward-looking statements, which reflect our current analysis of existing trends and information. However, there is an inherent risk that the actual results could differ materially. You can find a discussion of our risk factors, which could potentially contribute to such differences, in the company's Form 10-Q, which was filed earlier today, and our Form 10-K, which was filed on February 18. 
During today's call, we may also discuss certain non-GAAP financial measures. Reconciliations of these amounts with the comparable GAAP measures are reflected in our earnings release and posted in the Investor Relations section of our website at investors.fluor.com.
Now I'll turn the call over to David Seaton, Fluor's Chairman and CEO. David?

headline: Fluor Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Geoff. Good afternoon, and thank you for joining us today. On today's call, we'll review our first quarter results and discuss our outlook for the remainder of 2016. Before I get started, I wanted to comment on the tragedy that occurred 2 weeks
componenttext:
Thanks, Geoff. Good afternoon, and thank you for joining us today. On today's call, we'll review our first quarter results and discuss our outlook for the remainder of 2016. 
Before I get started, I wanted to comment on the tragedy that occurred 2 weeks ago in Mexico. As you may have read, 3 ICA Fluor employees and 29 subcontractors were killed in an explosion at PMV petrochemical plant in the state of Veracruz, Mexico. ICA Fluor was performing a revamp project at the site when the explosion occurred. The client is currently conducting their investigation in conjunction with the authorities and engaging with third-party experts into the cause of the accident. At this stage, there is no indication that the event was related to our activities at the site. So if you think I'm old somber today, I am. This is the worst accident in Fluor's history. This tragic event serves as a reminder to us all that we must hold our core value of safety at the center of all we do. At this very difficult time, our hearts are with the families and the friends of those killed in the tragic event.
Now moving to our first quarter results, I want to start by spending a few minutes sharing our perspective on the markets we serve. 
Global economic growth for the first quarter was weak, setting up another subpar year. Many economists have lowered their growth expectations for 2016. Crude oil and metal prices remain relatively low, which continues to suppress the cash flows of some of our customers and is causing some of the projects to shift to the right. For our commodity-influenced businesses, we are beginning to see clients reevaluate projects through studies and pre-FEEDs. Going forward, we do expect clients to continue to take a cautious, disciplined approach when they make their capital investment decisions. 
Low natural gas prices on the other hand continue to support investment in North American chemicals projects as well as gas-fired power plants. In fact, we're actively working on the beginning stages. We're bidding 4 separate new ethylene crackers in the United States. 
The recently passed FAST, which is Fixing America's Surface Transportation Act -- I'd like to know who comes up with these names. They're really inventive. It is supportive, however, of the new transportation infrastructure spend in the United States, and we expect the governments to be supportive of these investments in the infrastructure market. 
We also see good opportunities for growth in our industrial government and our maintenance capital markets. Our focus on the integrated solutions and capital efficiencies continues to resonate with our customers and has positioned us well for projects as they move forward. 
Finally, most of you have seen our release from last month's announcing our new reporting segments. We changed how we report our segments to better reflect how I and the rest of the management team view the diverse end markets that we serve. Business line results will now be segmented by our commodity-influenced businesses, Energy & Chemicals and Mining; our predominantly fixed-price businesses, Industrial & Infrastructure and Power; Government; and our operating expense-focused business, Maintenance, Modification & Asset Integrity. The MMAI group also includes our recent acquisition of Stork. 
Now let's look at our first quarter results beginning on Slide 3. Net earnings attributable to Fluor for the first quarter were $104 million or $0.74 per diluted share, excluding pretax expenses related primarily to the recent acquisition of Stork. Net earnings attributable to Fluor were $120 million or $0.85 per share compared with $114 million or $0.96 a year ago. 
Consolidated segment profit for the quarter was $241 million compared to $276 million a year ago. Improvements in our Government and Industrial, Infrastructure & Power segments were offset by declines in other segments. 
Segment profit. Margins were 5.5% compared to 5.4% last quarter and 6.1% a year ago.  Revenue for the quarter was $4.4 billion, comparable to the results reported last quarter and a year ago. New awards for the quarter were $4.7 billion. 
Consolidated backlog at the quarter-end was $46 billion, up 12% from $41.2 billion a year ago. Of the $5 billion increase, $1.5 billion is a result of our acquisition of Stork that was completed in the first quarter. 
Turning to Slide 4. Energy, Chemicals & Mining, booked $579 million in new awards. Ending backlog was $26.8 billion compared to $29.7 billion a year ago. Of this amount, only $481 million is in -- backlog is in mining. Now we believe the mining market will not significantly improved in the near future. 
First quarter new awards in Industrial, Infrastructure & Power were $1.4 billion and included the Loop 202 Freeway Project in Arizona. Looking ahead, we've been successful in weighing the South Carolina Port Access Road in Charleston, South Carolina, which will be a second quarter award, and the Maryland Purple Line project, which we expect to achieve financial close in the second half of this year. I am particularly encouraged by our successful bid in South Carolina, as it's a great example of our ability to be competitive on smaller but still critically important projects. I'm also pleased to report that the gas-fired power facility in Brunswick County, Virginia, is essentially complete with no additional charges in the quarter. 
Turning to Slide 5. The Government segment had a tremendous quarter with new awards of $2.3 billion. This includes the Idaho Cleanup Project and multiyear extension of the Portsmouth project, both in the DOE space. Ending backlog was $5.2 billion, up from $4.2 billion a year ago. 
The Maintenance, Modification & Asset Integrity segment posted new awards of $404 million, and ending backlog was $3.7 billion. 
Biggs will go into the details on our first quarter performance, but before he does, I want to give you some color on our changes in guidance for 2016.
We revised our -- our revised range takes into consideration the projects we are currently working on that we've seen stretch out over the last few months, with Sasol and Pemex as examples. Additionally, the process to reach FID continues to take longer than anticipated. Of course, this leads to the question on how we see 2017 shaping up, and my response is that while we have a nice backlog today that will support earnings in 2016 and beyond, it's still too early to tell when and how our clients will proceed with our capital deployment plans. 
With that, I'll now turn the call over to Biggs to review some of the details of the operating performance and corporate financial metrics. Biggs?

headline: Fluor Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Dave, and good afternoon, everyone. Please turn to Slide 6 of the presentation. I'll start by providing some additional comments on our first quarter performance, then move to the balance sheet. Revenue for the quarter was $4.4 billion, which co
componenttext:
Thanks, Dave, and good afternoon, everyone. Please turn to Slide 6 of the presentation. I'll start by providing some additional comments on our first quarter performance, then move to the balance sheet. 
Revenue for the quarter was $4.4 billion, which compares to $4.5 billion a year ago. Revenue gains from Industrial, infrastructure & Power and MMAI were offset by decline in mining activity within the Energy, Chemicals & Mining segment.  Operationally, this quarter was aligned with our expectations. This quarter's earnings per diluted share of $0.74 included cost related to our acquisition of Stork and an unrelated legal settlement. Excluding these expenses, the earnings per diluted share were $0.85. I also want to point out that first quarter results include only 1 month of Stork operations. Stork's business is seasonal with typically lower results in the first and fourth quarters. 
The tax rate for the quarter was higher than normal. There were a number of factors, including some nondeductible expenses, but the biggest contributor was losses that we weren't able to benefit for U.S. tax purposes. For the remaining 3 quarters, we expect the tax rate will be 34% to 36%. 
Corporate G&A expense for the first quarter was $55 million compared to $41 million a year ago. This increase was largely due to the Stork acquisition and a legal settlement I just mentioned. If were not those expenses, which aggregated into $22 million, G&A would have been down year-over-year. With the near-term softness of book and burn in the Energy, Chemicals & Mining segment, we will continue to be diligent by taking costs out of our model. 
Shifting to the balance sheet. Fluor's cash plus current and noncurrent marketable securities totaled $2 billion compared to $2.4 billion last quarter and $2.2 billion a year ago. During the quarter, we made our initial $350 million contribution to the COOEC Fluor fabrication joint venture in China. A second payment of $140 million will be made in the third quarter. 
Quarterly cash flow from operating activities was $115 million, and we paid $30 million in dividends. 
Moving to Slide 7. Fluor's consolidated backlog at quarter end was $46 million. The percentage of fixed price contracts in our overall backlog was 24% at quarter-end, and the mix by geography was sorted 43% U.S. and 57% non-U.S.
I will conclude my remarks by commenting on our guidance for 2016, which is on Slide 8. Although new awards and backlog position us well for the long term, clients in our Energy, Chemicals & Mining segment continue to stretch out existing work and defer issuing final investment decisions. Sasol's recent announcement of extending project construction at its petrochemical facility in Louisiana is but one example. 
To go ahead answer a frequent question in advance, there have been no significant cancellations, and we do not anticipate any. The burner backlog is low as we've all observed. Some of this was due to clients like Sasol and Pemex, where projects are well underway but have been stretched out, or Kitimat, which are on a slow pace. But much of it is due to the fact that many of the awards in backlog are very large and actually burn more slowly, such as the Westinghouse nuclear projects, and long-term O&M contracts on our recent infrastructure awards, and the multiyear government projects.  Backlog burn is also naturally [ph] slower, when backlog has grown as opposed to when it contracts. 
Having said all that, the delays in the project's stretch-out have a near-term effect. This has resulted in a lower-than-expected trajectory for full year revenue. Taking this consideration, the company is reducing its 2016 guidance range from $3.50 to $4 per diluted share to $3.25 to $3.65 per diluted share. 
Our guidance for 2016, included this Stork transaction and integration costs, also assumed G&A expense at the range of $200 million to $220 million. Other expectations for 2016 include NuScale's expenses of approximately $90 million, as we progress towards DCA submittal, which is targeted by the end of the year, and capital expenditures for the corporation of approximately $300 million. 
Under the new reporting segments, we anticipate near-term margins for the Energy, Chemicals & Mining group to be in the mid- to upper-6% range; Industrial, Infrastructure & Power, excluding NuScale, to be in the 4.5% to 5.5% range; Maintenance, Modification & Asset Integrity to be around 5% to 6%; and Government to be approximately 3%. 
With that, operator, we're ready to take questions.

headline: Fluor Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Wondering if you could just talk a little bit about how these 4 ethylene crackers will play out from a process perspective in terms of some of the timing on the FEED and NEPC, and if there's any that you feel that you particularly have stronger positionin
componenttext: Wondering if you could just talk a little bit about how these 4 ethylene crackers will play out from a process perspective in terms of some of the timing on the FEED and NEPC, and if there's any that you feel that you particularly have stronger positioning on.

headline: Fluor Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I think our success in the last round, I think, is a predicate to what I think we'll see this time. So I think our chances are really good. We're in a competitive FEED on when[ph]  that comes to the final bid. I think, Amanda -- well, it's the final
componenttext: Well, I think our success in the last round, I think, is a predicate to what I think we'll see this time. So I think our chances are really good. We're in a competitive FEED on when[ph]  that comes to the final bid. I think, Amanda -- well, it's the final decision is at the end of the year, but we finished the FEED and the proposal in the second quarter. There's, obviously, 2 more in the Gulf Coast that we are in the process of bidding for the FEED. So I think we're going to see some new awards this year in that next wave.

headline: Fluor Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then Biggs, you mentioned needing to be disciplined on costs in this environment, so what are you doing incrementally to take some more cost out? Where are you in your plans to move work offshore? And are there any other bigger-picture actions y
componenttext: Okay. And then Biggs, you mentioned needing to be disciplined on costs in this environment, so what are you doing incrementally to take some more cost out? Where are you in your plans to move work offshore? And are there any other bigger-picture actions you can take maybe to even go on the offensive here in this kind of weaker environment where you are the market leader?

headline: Fluor Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, as far as taking cost out, we just continue to look across the board at every opportunity. Of course, we should continue that for all time, but you obviously do it and look a little bit harder when any of the markets are challenged that we're operat
componenttext: Well, as far as taking cost out, we just continue to look across the board at every opportunity. Of course, we should continue that for all time, but you obviously do it and look a little bit harder when any of the markets are challenged that we're operating in. So when continue to look at taking out overhead costs but also costs that would be directly affecting our ability to perform [ph] on contracts to ensure we're as efficient as we can be across the board. So just it's pretty much across the board in terms of the looks that we take and the actions we're taking accordingly. In terms of being more aggressive, I think that we'll -- we're just going to stay prudent in terms of all of our investment activities. We always looked and we always look for areas in where we can make investments and create great returns for shareholders. But I don't think that philosophy or that attitude changes is more or less in these circumstances. I don't know, David, if you want to add to that.

headline: Fluor Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I'll just add one thing. Biggs, you're absolutely right. I'd add that in 2014, before the kind of the slowdown, we took over $100 million out of overhead during that year for a full run rate in '15 and obviously '16. So we're continuing to look at ou
componenttext: Yes, I'll just add one thing. Biggs, you're absolutely right. I'd add that in 2014, before the kind of the slowdown, we took over $100 million out of overhead during that year for a full run rate in '15 and obviously '16. So we're continuing to look at our model and the dispersed execution approach to see how we can leverage those resources around the globe. So I'm really pleased that we've been that diligent in kind of rightsizing the organization before we needed to. This business is kind of interesting when it slows and I think the industry is somewhat slow to React. And you're going to see, I think, some of our competitors probably have to do some drastic steps that we don't have to take. We've been very measured, very purposeful in how we've kind of reset the cost of doing business.

headline: Fluor Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: And we'll take our next question from Jamie Cook with Crédit Suisse.
componenttext: And we'll take our next question from Jamie Cook with Crédit Suisse.

headline: Fluor Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: I guess, just a question on the new guidance. I know the guidance includes the $0.11 associated with the transaction costs with Stork. I just want to get a better understanding of what you think the earnings contribution is from Stork so we can get a bett
componenttext: I guess, just a question on the new guidance. I know the guidance includes the $0.11 associated with the transaction costs with Stork. I just want to get a better understanding of what you think the earnings contribution is from Stork so we can get a better understanding of how much your -- how much of a deterioration is associated with the core business.

headline: Fluor Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: So back when we talked about -- I'm sorry, Jamie. This is Biggs. But I think in the last call, I said that we thought the contribution would be mild this year because of it being a part year but the integration transaction expenses being big offset. So th
componenttext: So back when we talked about -- I'm sorry, Jamie. This is Biggs. But I think in the last call, I said that we thought the contribution would be mild this year because of it being a part year but the integration transaction expenses being big offset. So that's still the case. Stork, it really isn't factored net-net to have much effect on this year. But next year, we certainly don't have the integration and transaction expenses we expect for synergies, which we think are going to be significant over time to be kicking in and for it to be accretive probably in the range of mid- to high single digits from a percent accretion standpoint next year. But some of those are going to be within Stork and some of them will be outside because we think that we have the opportunity to create more revenue and opportunity with this Stork as opposed it being a part of Fluor, but correspondingly that they had EPC opportunities that were available to them but which couldn't be fully fulfilled by them but now will be able to fulfill as a result of them being a part of the -- or us being the part of their offering.

headline: Fluor Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: But to -- so Biggs, we're all going to exclude the transactions costs, the onetime, $0.11, because we don't care about that. I guess, when we looked at the deal and the assumed margins, I think I was calculating like $0.30 accretion this year. So your int
componenttext: But to -- so Biggs, we're all going to exclude the transactions costs, the onetime, $0.11, because we don't care about that. I guess, when we looked at the deal and the assumed margins, I think I was calculating like $0.30 accretion this year. So your integration costs are going to offset that in total. So does that imply your core business is the decreased. If we look on an apples-to-apples basis and add back the $0.11, it's $0.20 in your core business. Is that the way to look at it? And then my follow-up question, David, would be, the slowing of the Sasol or Pemex, or whatever projects that are in energy, while it's a negative, I guess, looking at it the glass half full would be, assuming those are really good projects and they're not going out of backlog, to what degree does that help your 2017 profit so it's spread more evenly over 2 years versus the concern of a cliff of that? And then I'll be back in queue.

headline: Fluor Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Let me answer that one first and then, Biggs, you can answer the other one. It does put earnings in the outer years as projects are still going forward, but as you've seen most companies, they're looking at cash flow. So yes, it does help in the outer yea
componenttext: Let me answer that one first and then, Biggs, you can answer the other one. It does put earnings in the outer years as projects are still going forward, but as you've seen most companies, they're looking at cash flow. So yes, it does help in the outer years, but when the device orders is 4 years versus 3 years, obviously it's a lower number, just the math.

headline: Fluor Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, no, I know it's a lower number but not as big of a decline. You know what I mean [indiscernible]
componenttext: Well, no, I know it's a lower number but not as big of a decline. You know what I mean [indiscernible]

headline: Fluor Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I understand it, and I think that's a fair statement.
componenttext: Yes, I understand it, and I think that's a fair statement.

headline: Fluor Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, because you still feel good about those projects, we don't need to take them out of backlog?
componenttext: Okay, because you still feel good about those projects, we don't need to take them out of backlog?

headline: Fluor Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Oh, no, no. It is -- both of those programs, there's public announcements that they made about what they were doing and the fact that they were continuing. They were just dealing with cash flow issues. We were going to slow down a little bit.
componenttext: Oh, no, no. It is -- both of those programs, there's public announcements that they made about what they were doing and the fact that they were continuing. They were just dealing with cash flow issues. We were going to slow down a little bit.

headline: Fluor Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then, Biggs, just the core business, is it  -- I mean, was my math and everyone else's totally off, and is the core business is at the $0.20 hit to the 2016 EPS?
componenttext: Okay. And then, Biggs, just the core business, is it  -- I mean, was my math and everyone else's totally off, and is the core business is at the $0.20 hit to the 2016 EPS?

headline: Fluor Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, I think that you were a little high in terms of how you flowed Stork all the way through to the bottom line. Stork did have published financials previously. So there are numbers out there for their historical performance. But there was $100 million, r
componenttext: No, I think that you were a little high in terms of how you flowed Stork all the way through to the bottom line. Stork did have published financials previously. So there are numbers out there for their historical performance. But there was $100 million, roughly, of EBITDA at a run rate basis last year. We talked about that in the release where we announced the acquisition. But there were depreciation expenses and there are some noncontrolling interest and other elements to take into consideration. So if you just took that EBITDA number and floated through without a consideration of the other expenses, you'd probably end it up with too high an estimate. As to the rest of the business then, the -- there is some year-over-year decline in our equipment business, which we've talked about, and it was evident again this quarter. But otherwise, there is not a big year-over-year decline and everything else that you'd have to be factoring in. So I think your -- over time, we obviously expect Stork to be a big contributor, but you would have been high in that initial estimate. On second, integration expenses, you go ahead and so you can figure this as well. In total, the $0.11 we had for the quarter was integration transaction cost, plus there was a legal charge in there. We're going to have a little bit more in integration expenses over the remainder of the year, although it will certainly be less than what we had here in the first quarter. So it's just going to be a few million dollars more anyway.

headline: Fluor Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: And we'll take our next question from Andrew Kaplowitz from Citi.
componenttext: And we'll take our next question from Andrew Kaplowitz from Citi.

headline: Fluor Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: So can you talk about how we should think about, I guess, I'll call the new normal in Energy, Chemicals & Mining new awards? If we look at the last couple of years, you averaged a little more than $3 billion of new awards for the quarter, then you did $2
componenttext: So can you talk about how we should think about, I guess, I'll call the new normal in Energy, Chemicals & Mining new awards? If we look at the last couple of years, you averaged a little more than $3 billion of new awards for the quarter, then you did $2 billion last quarter before doing $600 million this quarter. Obviously, we know it's a rough quarter for the oil and gas sentiment, but how should we think about the average going forward? Do you have enough large projects in the pipeline? Or over the next year, you could come close to maintaining backlogs? Or should we put into our models closer to the last couple of quarters' average moving forward for a while?

headline: Fluor Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: We've used this term many, many times and others have picked up on it. It is the word lumpy. There is a couple of really large projects in that space that we believe will be awarded this quarter -- I mean, sorry, this year just in the out quarter. So I me
componenttext: We've used this term many, many times and others have picked up on it. It is the word lumpy. There is a couple of really large projects in that space that we believe will be awarded this quarter -- I mean, sorry, this year just in the out quarter. So I mean, I don't think the $1 billion is the normal run rate going forward, but I'd hate to put a number on it given the volatility of the decision-making. But there are still some very, very large projects that we believe will be -- we'll take into backlog this year.

headline: Fluor Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, that's fine, David. And I know you don't want to talk about 2017 too much, but maybe we can talk about the puts and takes on EPS as we sit here today. If you're talking about incremental EPS from Stork, maybe that's still $0.20 or more. You've got m
componenttext: Okay, that's fine, David. And I know you don't want to talk about 2017 too much, but maybe we can talk about the puts and takes on EPS as we sit here today. If you're talking about incremental EPS from Stork, maybe that's still $0.20 or more. You've got maybe $0.15 of lower spend on NuScale. You got additional buybacks and maybe something from the new shipyard. Those things could help offset lower oil  and gas and earnings. Am I missing anything in sort of the puts and takes? And it's a pretty sizable tailwind to give you a shot, I guess, at growing earnings in '17.

headline: Fluor Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, all those things are in some form or fashion accurate. This isn't our first rodeo, so to speak. And when industry takes a deep breath like their oil and gas industry has and they push things to the right, one of the unintended consequences of that i
componenttext: Well, all those things are in some form or fashion accurate. This isn't our first rodeo, so to speak. And when industry takes a deep breath like their oil and gas industry has and they push things to the right, one of the unintended consequences of that is what could end up being a boom as we get into the out years because they still got to do these developments. I mean, I've said this before. I mean, it's 10 years from a exploration well to production, and certain companies have to put every year something in the neighborhood of 200,000 barrels a day back into their reserve base just to stay flat. So spending will continue. It's not like they've stopped spending. In fact, in Chevron's call, they talked about the Tengiz project continuing to go forward, which we're clearly working on that job. So there is upside there. But I think as we get into a little bit later into this year, we'll see. I mean, I think there is still significant production just in Texas alone that are still based on financial hedges. So there are still people being paid $60 a barrel that will end as we get into the summer. So you are going to see -- this is David Seaton's crystal ball, you're going to see the glut of those projects clear reasonably quickly to where I believe you'll see oil inch up to somewhere in the low 50s as we get into the first half of next year. I think most companies have gotten really comfortable with that $40 being the new norm, $50 being the new norm, and they'll start their spending again. So I think what I'm really pleased with is the fact that in the face of that, the diversity of our company allowed us to have what was a really good no-award quarter. And we see those markets continuing to grow. As I mentioned, in the prepared remarks, I'm really pleased with that South Carolina award because it proves that our new model can produce much more efficient and effective competitive bids. When you look at that market just alone, the infrastructure market, there is going to be a hell of a lot more $200 million jobs than $2 billion jobs. And there's going to be those 2 like the Purple Line project. But it shows that the diversity allows us to skate to where the puck is going to be, to steal from Gretzky, and I think we'll continue to do that. There's lots of programs in the industrial space. There is very large pharmaceutical biotech projects that we're chasing. There's a lot more government work that we're chasing. There's power projects that we're chasing. So the opportunity slate is still pretty robust even in oil and gas. And I think we're well positioned to be much more competitive than we've been in the past, and clearly, we're going to be contractor of choice.

headline: Fluor Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: David, that's helpful. Biggs, just a quick clarification. The new nuclear projects as they came in, they were the profitability you expected? I mean, I know there was a NuScale headwind in the quarter year-over-year. But your $300 million of new revenue w
componenttext: David, that's helpful. Biggs, just a quick clarification. The new nuclear projects as they came in, they were the profitability you expected? I mean, I know there was a NuScale headwind in the quarter year-over-year. But your $300 million of new revenue with only $2 million of more profit, so was that just the NuScale headwind in there that caused that?

headline: Fluor Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, there -- the nuclear margin rate is as we expected and no headwind in that regard. The -- of course, yes, they're completing one project that we had reported a loss last year, so that's coming in a 0 margin this year. But other than that, everything,
componenttext: Yes, there -- the nuclear margin rate is as we expected and no headwind in that regard. The -- of course, yes, they're completing one project that we had reported a loss last year, so that's coming in a 0 margin this year. But other than that, everything, as expected and many real variants, yes, that is driven by year-over-year on NuScale.

headline: Fluor Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, on the mix, we've only been on there for 3 months, and in fact, in one case, we only took over the craft at the end of March. So there was 0 -- virtually 0 margin associated with those craft. Now they're fully on board, and the next quarter, I think
componenttext: Well, on the mix, we've only been on there for 3 months, and in fact, in one case, we only took over the craft at the end of March. So there was 0 -- virtually 0 margin associated with those craft. Now they're fully on board, and the next quarter, I think, will prove out to be a little bit better in terms of those 2 projects.

headline: Fluor Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: And we'll move to our next question from Tahira Afzal with KeyBanc.
componenttext: And we'll move to our next question from Tahira Afzal with KeyBanc.

headline: Fluor Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: So, David, first question is the Chinese fab yard. Would you have bought it at the time you did, is it a bit of a drag on the utilization side? Could you have bought something else in hindsight? Or is it really helping you from a longer-term standpoint an
componenttext: So, David, first question is the Chinese fab yard. Would you have bought it at the time you did, is it a bit of a drag on the utilization side? Could you have bought something else in hindsight? Or is it really helping you from a longer-term standpoint and remaining competitors?

headline: Fluor Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: No. I still made the decision. It's going to be a great asset for us, currently and longer term. In looking at the opportunity slate, the prospect list that we got today, there's projects on there today that weren't on there before because we have access
componenttext: No. I still made the decision. It's going to be a great asset for us, currently and longer term. In looking at the opportunity slate, the prospect list that we got today, there's projects on there today that weren't on there before because we have access to that sort of fabrication capability. So I think it's a great decision. I think the earnings are pushed out, but they're active right now. There's 2 projects in that yard right now for C nuke [ph]. So it's an active yard. Yes, we'd like to have more tonnage in there, and there will be, but clearly, it's opened up an opportunity slate to us that didn't exist before.

headline: Fluor Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got it, David. And, David, there's some pretty large financing, like a $15 billion type of petrochem complex that is now being exposed in China. Does this yard help you within China as well?
componenttext: Got it, David. And, David, there's some pretty large financing, like a $15 billion type of petrochem complex that is now being exposed in China. Does this yard help you within China as well?

headline: Fluor Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, it can. It absolutely can. The difference is, is that labor is relatively cheap in China, and they like to stick-build things. But yes, there's opportunities for us in the non-offshore business in China.
componenttext: Yes, it can. It absolutely can. The difference is, is that labor is relatively cheap in China, and they like to stick-build things. But yes, there's opportunities for us in the non-offshore business in China.

headline: Fluor Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got it. And last question is, as you talk to your clients, is it more the volatility at this point? Given costs across the whole life cycle of Oil & Gas projects have been brought so much, is it the volatility that's hurting the timing and release of proj
componenttext: Got it. And last question is, as you talk to your clients, is it more the volatility at this point? Given costs across the whole life cycle of Oil & Gas projects have been brought so much, is it the volatility that's hurting the timing and release of projects? So if oil was to stay, let's say, between $45 to $50 or something over the next year, there's more of a chance that projects would be released? Or is it just the level still?

headline: Fluor Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's kind of all the above. I mean -- and the customers that I talked to, it's cash flow and dealing with cash flow as it related to what our plans were. So there's that deep breath taking place and prioritization of projects. That's point #1. Point #2, t
componenttext: It's kind of all the above. I mean -- and the customers that I talked to, it's cash flow and dealing with cash flow as it related to what our plans were. So there's that deep breath taking place and prioritization of projects. That's point #1. Point #2, they were already upset that the amount these projects were costing and, hence, why we spent the time and effort to kind of retool the way we've done things and become more competitive, because capital efficiency is the term that we're living by right now, which is what our customers are looking for. And then I think that the oil price clearly has the impact in terms of what their appetite is going to be. But I think it's just a timing element, in most cases, for a lot of these big programs. I mean, if you think about it, Biggs in his prepared remarks said that we don't have any expectation of cancellations. We also believe there are going to be significant projects go to FID this year and be awarded to us this year. So I think it's a little bit of volatility, but I think it's also some really thoughtful looks at their programs and projects to make sure they've got the best price for these programs and projects.

headline: Fluor Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got it, David. I mean, if you look at completions, are you seeing some pretty large projects complete this year? Or is the stretch helping you in terms of visibility for the longer term? In other words, are you really dependent more so next year on large
componenttext: Got it, David. I mean, if you look at completions, are you seeing some pretty large projects complete this year? Or is the stretch helping you in terms of visibility for the longer term? In other words, are you really dependent more so next year on large -- on gas projects than you were for this year?

headline: Fluor Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, we really don't have any of the large ones completing this year. When you think -- in Oil & Gas, when you think about mining, most of those were complete, and we just don't see a whole lot of expenditure. There's the onesies and twosies that will come
componenttext: No, we really don't have any of the large ones completing this year. When you think -- in Oil & Gas, when you think about mining, most of those were complete, and we just don't see a whole lot of expenditure. There's the onesies and twosies that will come in, in that marketplace. But no, I think the explanation that Biggs gave in the prepared remarks, I think, kind of speaks to the fact that these programs and projects are bigger, they are longer in schedule and, therefore, they earn over a longer period of time. So when I think of our backlog, I think we've got a really solid base of work that's going to burn a little bit slower than we've seen in past history.

headline: Fluor Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: And we'll take our next question from Chad Dillard with Deutsche Bank.
componenttext: And we'll take our next question from Chad Dillard with Deutsche Bank.

headline: Fluor Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: So you've won a pretty decent amount of infrastructure work so far. So I'd be just curious to hear about what you're seeing going forward. And do you think you have enough capacity to absorb the additional infrastructure work? And do you think you'll be a
componenttext: So you've won a pretty decent amount of infrastructure work so far. So I'd be just curious to hear about what you're seeing going forward. And do you think you have enough capacity to absorb the additional infrastructure work? And do you think you'll be able to pull other underutilized individuals from the rest of your -- from the rest of the area to help them out?

headline: Fluor Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Absolutely. I don't think we got any issues with capacity, frankly, in any of the markets that we serve. There's pieces that we want to improve and skill sets that we need to go get. But when you look at -- we just finished, and actually, I participated i
componenttext: Absolutely. I don't think we got any issues with capacity, frankly, in any of the markets that we serve. There's pieces that we want to improve and skill sets that we need to go get. But when you look at -- we just finished, and actually, I participated in the ribbon-cutting of the Denver light rail project last week or 2 weeks ago. And many of those people are headed to the Purple Line in Maryland. So we feel pretty good about our place in the infrastructure market. And frankly speaking, we see that as one of the growth areas. As you mentioned, we've been very successful this year. But I'd point you to last year where we were very unsuccessful, by and large, because of some predatory pricing by the competition. So not only do we see good opportunity, but we also have good solid projects in terms of backlog margin as we burn that and as we execute. So I'm pretty bullish on the infrastructure market. And as I said in the previous question and the prepared remarks, the fact that we can be competitive in an open procurement on a $200-kind-of million project, I think, bodes well for that group.

headline: Fluor Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great. And then with your new guidance, so at the midpoint, is what you have in the backlog currently enough to get you there? Or do you need to win more work?
componenttext: Great. And then with your new guidance, so at the midpoint, is what you have in the backlog currently enough to get you there? Or do you need to win more work?

headline: Fluor Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, we always need to win new work. I mean, I'm not going to get into what percentage of backlog is there, but we always need to book -- we always need to win new work for book and burn to hit any of the numbers, any of the years, any of the quarters. A
componenttext: Well, we always need to win new work. I mean, I'm not going to get into what percentage of backlog is there, but we always need to book -- we always need to win new work for book and burn to hit any of the numbers, any of the years, any of the quarters. And there's nobody in the market space any different.

headline: Fluor Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, but we do try to assess the range of outcomes in that regard when we set the range.
componenttext: Yes, but we do try to assess the range of outcomes in that regard when we set the range.

headline: Fluor Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Correct.
componenttext: Correct.

headline: Fluor Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: And we'll move to our next question from Andy Wittmann with Robert W. Baird.
componenttext: And we'll move to our next question from Andy Wittmann with Robert W. Baird.

headline: Fluor Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: The Portsmouth award was a large award. I was curious over how many years that award is expected to burn.
componenttext: The Portsmouth award was a large award. I was curious over how many years that award is expected to burn.

headline: Fluor Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, the Portsmouth was not the big one. The big one was Idaho. Portsmouth is a 30-month extension. Idaho is a 3-year contract with 2 extension -- potential extension years. And we wouldn't have booked the extension years.
componenttext: Well, the Portsmouth was not the big one. The big one was Idaho. Portsmouth is a 30-month extension. Idaho is a 3-year contract with 2 extension -- potential extension years. And we wouldn't have booked the extension years.

headline: Fluor Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. So you just have the 3 years, and then it's, what, plus 1, plus 1?
componenttext: Okay. So you just have the 3 years, and then it's, what, plus 1, plus 1?

headline: Fluor Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Correct.

componenttext: I wanted to focus on the Industrial & Infrastructure segment for a second. So if you're looking at smaller infrastructure projects, does it change the way you bid for these projects? Does it change your risk profile? And eventually, what does it mean for margins?

headline: Fluor Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, it -- our approach to bidding projects and how we look at risk has not changed and will not change in a market condition -- even in the market conditions we find ourselves in. So we're going to be very, very diligent in terms of that. So I think the k
componenttext: No, it -- our approach to bidding projects and how we look at risk has not changed and will not change in a market condition -- even in the market conditions we find ourselves in. So we're going to be very, very diligent in terms of that. So I think the kind of margin that we've seen on some of the bigger projects, we're going to continue to see in these smaller projects. So really no change at all in terms of how we bid or aggressiveness therefore.

headline: Fluor Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I think -- there's 2 pieces to it, right? And I think -- well, actually, 3 pieces. The first piece is I think it gives the states confidence. I'm talking about just specifically U.S. It gives the states confidence to push some of these things throug
componenttext: Well, I think -- there's 2 pieces to it, right? And I think -- well, actually, 3 pieces. The first piece is I think it gives the states confidence. I'm talking about just specifically U.S. It gives the states confidence to push some of these things through, that there will be some federal funding associated with what they've got to do. Every state that we really focus on has significant legislation on -- in the works, I'll say, that support a very large amount of projects to come to fruition. The other piece is going to be some of these shovel-ready projects in fixing potholes to everything else. We're not really going to focus on that. But every one of these programs that these states are looking at have significant bridge work, have significant toll road opportunities, which the public-private partnership, which is the last piece, are going to have to play a role. Now one of the things that some of the states need to do is they need to make it legal to do public-private partnerships for infrastructure programs. Not every state has that kind of law in the books that allows it. But I think that we're finally at a point where the deterioration of the infrastructure in the United States is to a point where we got to do something. This Port Access Project is just the first piece of the Charleston Port expansion. So winning this one puts us in a good position to get the next one. But there's lots and lots of programs that we're going to have access to, and I'm really pretty bullish on that market. But again, I'm not sure it's going to be this year that we're going to see significantly new awards because these projects take a long time to put together. And I'll point to the Eagle P3 Project in Denver. That project started in discussion in 2003, and we just opened it. So there's a long tail to these things. But they've got a good earnings stream, and they're over a long period of time. When you look at the Eagle P3, we've got a 28-year maintenance contract that started when we opened it last week. So again, it goes to another question that was asked. When you look at the infrastructure, it builds a good base over the longer term that we can use to grow from.

Other than that, those projects kind of hit the ground running because they're already underway. So it's a $5 billion award over roughly 5 years. You've got [indiscernible] 20% of that burning each year. So it was just in rough terms. That's how you look at the burn within the Industrial & Infrastructure and Power segment being affected by those awards. This is interesting because it is instant book and burn, but it still brings the average burn rate down because it's a 5-year project. Other than that, I think that there's no other rule anomalies to point out. It's an interesting question. That's one thing that I don't know that we recast for everybody was historical backlog numbers to -- so that they can see what historical book and burn would be. So let me go back and look at that and see if there's a way to help you on it.

headline: Fluor Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: A lot of the resources are fungible within the company, and we have the ability to move people around to different projects. So I don't think, from a leadership perspective, it's -- we really have an issue. We're always going to bring new people in with t
componenttext: A lot of the resources are fungible within the company, and we have the ability to move people around to different projects. So I don't think, from a leadership perspective, it's -- we really have an issue. We're always going to bring new people in with the skills that we need. When you look at what's in front of us, obviously, light rail is going to be important. So we're going to need rail expertise. As I mentioned, there's going to be a lot of bridge works, so we're going to need some bridge expertise. So I feel pretty good in being able to bring those folks on as necessary. And we'll clearly add the additive to that. But I don't see a capacity issue. And we've added -- when you think about the resources from the 2 nukes in Stork, we're over 60,000 employees now. And I still believe we're the employer of choice given our ability to retain people. So I think that we can move -- we're going to reallocate resources around the globe. I think our dispersed model is working and showing that we don't need to hire and fire like the normal cycles have dictated in the past. I'd point to Houston as an example, and it's been as high as -- at least in the last little while, as high as 4,800 people. And it's around 2,800 people now, and it has been for 2.5 years -- 3 years. And we don't expect it to drop much more than that. So again, some of the things we've done to perfect the dispersed execution model, I think, gives us a lot more stability in the -- across the portfolio, but it also shows that when we need to turn the crank, we can bring in the people we need almost regardless of how big we need to be.

componenttext: But even at that level, I mean, we're not -- we're still well below the peaks we've seen a couple of times before. And do you have to reposition Fluor or think about other markets to keep the growth going so that you're even more successful with the next cycle?

headline: Fluor Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, I don't think so. And I've said this in previous discussions with some of you. I lived in Saudi Arabia in the '90s. And I remember 1997, oil was $17 a barrel, up from $11. And even though oil is in the places where it's more difficult to get to, then
componenttext: No, I don't think so. And I've said this in previous discussions with some of you. I lived in Saudi Arabia in the '90s. And I remember 1997, oil was $17 a barrel, up from $11. And even though oil is in the places where it's more difficult to get to, then maybe then, they were still -- Saudi Aramco was still spending $30 billion a year, right? So they're still going to spend at $40 and $50 and $60. And they don't need to get back, in most cases, to peak for them to be efficient and profitable. So I don't think we need to retool any more than we've already retooled because I think the things that we've done to become more competitive and satisfy that capital efficiency need by our customers puts us in a position to be extremely robust and profitable as we go into the next wave.

componenttext: David, I was hoping you could maybe just talk a little bit about Stork on the revenue side. You talked about incremental opportunities. I know it's only been 2 months since the acquisition closed. But are you seeing any new opportunities kind of outside of the core Stork business yet? Or any color on that?

headline: Fluor Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I mean, I -- it's not a high revenue-type company. I mean, it's basically service revenue people. So you're not going to see a huge bump in revenue, but I think we'll see some good bumps in profitability. The short answer is absolutely. We're already
componenttext: Yes, I mean, I -- it's not a high revenue-type company. I mean, it's basically service revenue people. So you're not going to see a huge bump in revenue, but I think we'll see some good bumps in profitability. The short answer is absolutely. We're already seeing opportunities that arise that maybe we didn't have access to before. I think that the fact that Stork is owned by Fluor now gives customers confidence that they're there for the longer term. There might have been some question before in terms of their viability. The -- so we're seeing great response from the customers in terms of their interest in hiring Stork. And we're in some markets where Fluor physically wasn't present that helps Fluor in those geographic regions. There's lots of headroom, I believe, in the U.S. Gulf Coast. When you look at the installed capital base in the Gulf Coast, it's a huge number of facilities and assets that need to be managed and need maintenance and modification, shutdown, turnaround, those kinds of things that makes Fluor very attractive in terms of their delivery model. So I think that we just kind of scratched the surface, and I think there's great growth opportunity for that segment of the business.

componenttext: Yes, just anecdotally, as soon as the transaction was announced, Stork management had incoming phone calls from their customers saying, "Great. Now they're going to be a part of Fluor. We'd like you to propose on doing this or increasing the scope for that." So clearly, there's benefits associated with the 2 companies being together.

componenttext: Okay. And then kind of a bigger picture question, David. One of the oil majors earlier this week was talking about bringing more of their early engineering in-house, and I think this has been going on for a while. But they just started talking about it publicly. And I don't expect that this would impact the size of your market opportunity. But are there longer-term or bigger picture implications from this if other companies start doing more of it? Is it something that affects competition later on in the project life cycle? Does it affect your visibility? I don't know if this is a trend you're watching, but I thought I'd ask about it.

headline: Fluor Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, it's a good question. We've seen this before, and we certainly see it now. I would argue that it's a huge mistake because, typically, those people don't do the types of services that we do. We've got real examples where that has happened in terms of F
componenttext: No, it's a good question. We've seen this before, and we certainly see it now. I would argue that it's a huge mistake because, typically, those people don't do the types of services that we do. We've got real examples where that has happened in terms of FEED projects in Oil & Gas in previous cycles and not that long ago where they had people available, so they said, "Well, let's let them do the FEED." And then they came to us to actually redo the FEED because the answer that they got was too expensive and not the right schedule. So I -- they probably don't like to hear me say that. But we're really good at those kinds of things, and they're really good at producing product. And we're better positioned -- our industry is better positioned to do those kinds of things. But they've got pressures that they've got to deal with in terms of employment. In some cases, they can't ebb and flow like a company like ours can, and we understand that. And we'll be there to help them when they need it.

headline: Fluor Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, operator, and thanks to all of you for participating today. As I said in the opening remarks and certainly in the Q&A, we continue to see that low commodity prices driving customers to extend projects and delay FID decisions based on cash flow.
componenttext:
Thank you, operator, and thanks to all of you for participating today. As I said in the opening remarks and certainly in the Q&A, we continue to see that low commodity prices driving customers to extend projects and delay FID decisions based on cash flow. This, I think, coupled with a little bit slower pace associated with some of the larger projects, we've won over the past couple of years. In the long term, O&M contracts we've recently put into place in infrastructure and others have a slower burn and might provide, I think, a more stable revenue trajectory. 
The revised 2016 guidance range reflects, I think, this reality. While our capital structure is sound and our cash flow generation remains robust, we remain disciplined in how we use our cash, and we'll continue to do so as we look at lowering our cost of business and internal costs associated with it. 
Finally, we continue to invest for the long term. As you've seen with our recent investments in the fab yard and certainly Stork, it positions our company to not only take care of capture market share in the traditional markets, but it also allows us to show growth in some of the longer-term aspects of our business. 
And with that, we greatly appreciate your interest in Fluor and your confidence in our company. Thank you, and have a good evening.

headline: Fluor Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
